title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. I predict he will live to regret it. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: queen must be firm harry meghan
story: So we hope that Meghan and Harry can come to a suitable arrangement with the rest of the royals.But what’s clear is the couple must not receive a penny from the state.British taxpayers fund the Royal Family to strengthen our nation’s soft power, and to support vital charities.If Meghan and Harry can’t be bothered with the legwork, then it goes without saying they must give up the whopping perks which come with it.As for security, claims that to stay safe the pair need cash from daddy just won’t wash. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are rich beyond the wildest dreams of almost everyone in the UK.They are more than capable of paying for a few bodyguards. Andthey find themselves struggling, they could always cut down on the private jets.The Queen, Charles and Wills must be firm: the Sussexes have made their bed. Now they’ve got to lie in it.A CIVILISED nation treats its veterans with respect.Which is why we were delighted when Boris Johnson won the election on a manesto promising to end witch hunt prosecutions against ageing former soldiers who served in Northern Ireland.But to get Stormont up and running, the Prime Minister has brokered a deal with Sinn Fein which risks opening up new probes into thousands of Troubles veterans. This would be morally indefensible and politically mad.Yes, a working government in Northern Ireland would be a good thing. But the safety and wellbeing of our elderly veterans is too big a price tag.And given Boris won the election by being a proud patriot, it makes political sense for him to stand by the armed forces through thick and thin.If the PM is to hold the hard-earned trust of new Conservative voters, he must never give way to those who would put our old soldiers in the dock.IT would be fair to assume that anyone injecting plastic into someone’s face should have some qualications to do so.But a strange loophole in the law means that though Botox is classied as a medicine in Britain, dermal fillers aren’t covered by any regulation.A staggering  per cent of facial fillers are performed by people with no medical training, often in unsanitary conditions — with devastating results.Which is why The Sun’s Fabulous brand is launching the Had Our Fill campaign, urging for a crackdown on unregulated cosmetic fillers, and raising awareness to help women make safer, more informed choices.We’ve had our fill of dodgy fillers. title: queen mistake reign harry meghan demands
story: The public will be repulsedthese two quitters continue to make a penny from them — and yes, that includes the ancient Duchy of Cornwall, which Prince Charles only inherited as the monarch’s eldest son.But that’s only the start. Letting them keep their titles to amass a Kardashian-sized fortune cashing in on their royal status will be a grotesque abuse of the monarchy and taxpayers who fund it.What will the public get in   Nothing.Meanwhile this revered ,-year-old institution will be reduced to an Instagram marketing tool for one jaw- droppingly self-centred young couple.We never really thought this scandal could threaten the monarchy.But its image looks in mortal danger and its finances may have to be rapidly reviewedHarry and Meghan still receive seven-figure sums from Charles despite having £million in the bank.We appreciate the Queen’s plight, at  and wanting only the best for the grandson she loves.But this was a moment not for a fudge but for ruthlessness to secure the monarchy’s future: No money, no titles, no using the royal name.Do your duty, in full, or go it alone, in full, as private citizens.At least we heard one dose of sound sense — when Home Secretary Priti Patel angrily rubbished leftie claims that the Press, and Britain, is “racist” towards Meghan.It is fact-free drivel.And this is just about the LEAST prejudiced nation on Earth.This couple have simply raised the bar for self-obsessed, arrogant entitlement.WE sympathise with Labour members ­having to feign enthusiasm for the remaining contenders for Jeremy Corbyn’s job.Mind you, the five finalists could barely do worse than Jezza, possibly except his naive disciple Rebecca Long-Bailey, the Tories’ dream candidate.The rest include sneering Islington lawyer Emily Thornberry, whose loathing of working-class Britain is mutual. And gobby Jess Phillips, who thinks insulting Boris alone will win her power.There’s Lisa Nandy, almost certainly too sensible. And then there’s millionaire QC Sir Keir Starmer, the favourite and the only bloke left, which means Labour is almost sure to pick him since its “ersity” is a pose.But let’s shatter one Labour delusion.None of these scares the Tories. The election’s over. The Government has an -seat majority and five years in power.So we have three suggestions for Labour: bin Twitter, which has been disastrously discombobulating for the party.Forget your juvenile morality war against Boris. title: meghan markle racism press bigotry
story: By “they” I mean the liberal-Left commentariat, the people who hate Brexit, hate ordinary people and have, for some reason, grown to love our departing royals, Prince Harry and Meghan.This past  hours they have closed ranks around the couple, who have announced they plan to keep their royal titlesbut leave behind their royal duties — like some woke version of the Queen’s Guard.They have chastised anyone outraged by the staggering entitlement shown by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who have essentially said they want the status but none of the responsibilities of monarchy.They insist the poor couple have been driven out by racism.British author Afua Hirsch, writing in the New York Times, decries the “racist treatment of Meghan” in the Press.She says it is hardly a surprise Meghan has walked away from a nation with a Prime Minister “whose track record includes overtly racist statements” and a “Brexit project linked to native nationalism”.Boris Johnson has no such track record and the only people linking Brexit to native nationalism are elitist, upper-crust Remainers like Hirsch.But no matter. Why let reality spoil the narrative These claims made about the “racist” treatment of Meghan at the hands of the British Press are incredibly thin.The same non-examples are recycled over and over again. You have probably seen them quoteda thousand times.There is that Mail Online piece from , when Harry and Meghan were first dating, that said she was “ straight outta Compton”.At the time, Meghan’s mother Doria Ragland lived in nearby Crenshaw, LA.Hirsch says this was an attempt to link Meghan with “racialised forms of crime”, meaning gangs.That is one hell of a reach. The piece was clearly just playing on the dference in Harry and Meghan’s social backgrounds.If Harry had been dating a white, working-class woman from Manchester’s Moss Side, I dare say the Mail would have done something similarly silly.Another favourite is that weird throwaway line Boris Johnson’s sister Rachel wrote, in a laudatory piece on Meghan, about the mixed-race American actress bringing some “rich and exotic DNA” to the pale Windsor bloodline. That is more cringey than racist.Several pieces have cited a single phrase in a Sarah Vine column for the Mail — she said she had a “niggling worry” about the royal couple’s engagement photo — as a bigoted dog whistle. That is, quite frankly, mental.Such is the lack of actual examples of the Press being racist about Meghan.The only leg this argument has left to stand on is that the sheer volume of criticism sent Meghan’s way was disproportionate.Racism is the only explanation for it. It’s an argument based purely on unveriable speculation and imputing motives. It is also b*****ks.When the couple first got together, the coverage was gushing across the board.It was only when Meghan and Harry started on their ious virtue-signalling cru-sades — such as jetting around to lecture on climate change — that people’s backs went up.That the couple had already been beefing with the Press probably didn’t help either.In , way before Meghan became a figure in our culture wars, Harry issued a remarkable statement rebuking journalists for the “racial undertones” of their pieces.That these privileged royals, kept in the lap of luxury at taxpayers’ expense, began to develop a deep-seated victim complex only heightened the resentment towards them.Last year, Meghan told ITV public le was a “struggle” and she was shocked that “not many people have askedI’m OK”. Poor princess.This picture of privilege is who the liberal Left has spent the best part of three years defending.Even supposed republicans have — after a bit of anti-royal throat-clearing — defended Harry and Meghan to the hilt and helped con- struct this absurd narrative that they are the victims of establishment racism.This says far more about the prejudices of liberal-Left commentators than it does about the tabloid Press. title: meghan markle not pitchforked off uk
story: It follows the fortunes, or rather, misfortunes, of Americans who fall in love with foreigners and have just over three months to get married or send them home.A massive leap of faith, it’s usually a matter of days — sometimes hours — before the clash of cultures, personalities, values and expectations make this the television gt that keeps on giving.Perhaps Meghan and Harry should sign up for season eight. For how much did they really know about each other before walking down the aisle Prince William apparently advised his more impetuous brother to wait so he could really get to know his American bride first, but Harry took umbrage and didn’t listen.Perhapshe had, he might have worked out in advance that an independent spirit joining such a restrictive institution wasn’t going to end well.Instead, they leapt before they looked and, with the “-month bride” having packed her bags already, have saddled the -year-old Queen with yet another constitutional crisis.Back in , I wrote a piece defending Meghan after she was criticised by old school friend Ninaki Priddy for being “calculated in the way she handled people and relationships” and a “curator of a beautul le”.But following the lavish baby shower, the jet-setting with A-listers and the swt jettisoning of inconveniently outspoken family members, the latter sentiment now rings true.And, of course, becoming a member of the most famous royal family in the world was the cherry on the top of that beautul le.But Meghan soon discovered it was nothing like the membership of her beloved Soho House.The rooms are draughty, the decor chintzy and, instead of reading the morning papers in your cashmere loungewear, you have to rise early, put on a frock and make your way to some rain-lashed outpost to open the new wing of a community centre where “live your best le” sentiments, however well-meaning, aren’t required.Here’s what is required as a member of the British Royal Family: Turn up on time, shake hands, smile, say little more than “have you come far ” Repeat.Not because the royals don’t have anything to say. They do, and air their views in private.But in public, their job is to shine a light on whatever project they’re visiting, not themselves. To show — via action, not virtue-signalling statements — a strong sense of duty.And inthey get to keep their ious mansions, hundreds of staff, personal bodyguards etc without any whf of civil unrest.That’s the deal.But those still in Meghan’s social circle glowingly describe her as organised, focused, and opinionated — very much an independent woman used to having her voice heard.As Prince Harry told courtiers just before their wedding: “What Meghan wants, Meghan gets.”An admirable quality when it comes to breaking through the glass ceiling of corporate le or securing the best table in the best restaurant, perhaps.But the monarchy is an institution steeped in hundreds of years of tradition, and Meghan — who claimed she “didn’t know much” about Harry when they first met — clearly thought she’d mould it to her way of thinking . . . then rapidly discovered that it ain’t for turning.Not that The Queen didn’t try very hard to accommodate the wants and needs of the newly anointed Duke and Duchess of Sussex.Contrary to royal tradition, they were permitted to keep the christening of baby Archie as a private affair and, despite there being a perfectly nice home at Kensington Palace they could have used, a publicly funded, £.million renovation of Frogmore Cottage was authorised.A “cottage” I might add, that used to be five homes but has now been knocked in to one because they managed to dodge the usual ban that prevents such moves because of the UK’s housing crisis.Shortly after, Prince Charles launched his blueprint to try to solve the dilemma faced by millions of young people struggling to find a home of their own. Oh the irony. And after all that, they now want to use it part-time as they flit back and forth across the Atlantic.Meghan is feeling disillusioned and homesick. We get it, and sympathise.But let’s not pretend, as some claim, that she’s been practically pitchforked off this island by racist bigots.This is not a racist country and, besides, the British public initially greeted her engagement and later marriage to Harry with unbridled joy.We love Harry. He’s a thoroughly decent person and deserves particular praise for the work he’s done with the Armed Forces, both while serving and afterwards.No, the disconnect has come from the fact that Meghan is still a Hollywood celebrity at heart and, consequently, never truly settled in her often boring and restrictive new role.She misses the relative freedom of her old le, not to mention her family and friends.Again, we get it. But was it really necessary to flee these shores asescaping for her le Clearly besotted with her, Harry faces the stark decision of giving her what she wants or losing her for ever. Or perhaps he’s genuinely sick of royal le and wants out too.If so, let’s wave goodbye and wish them luck.But. The have-cake-and-eat-it plan to stop being a “senior royal” and just dip in and out of duties that suit them simply isn’t going to work.SussexRoyal — which Harry and Meghan have registered as an official trademark for everything from “emotional support services” to clothing and magazines — is a title and privilege that comes with duties and conditions attached, not a brand, be it charitable or otherwise.The future of the monarchy depends on the goodwill, support and interest level of the public, and a recent survey showed that, while the majority have no issue with their decision to go, they were strongly against any continued taxpayer funding of their lavish lestyle.So— as early indicators go — The Queen allows Harry and Meghan to call the shots while keeping their royal titles, their taxpayer-funded security and an allowance from the Duchy of Cornwall, then one suspects this will be discussed by students for centuries to come as the turning point at which the British monarchy began its steady decline to irrelevance and, ultimately, abolition.MOVIE mega-star Will Smith popped in to the retirement party of a woman he last met  years ago.Anita Scipio was the receptionist at a US radio station when Will arrived for one of his first interviews as a young actor and he’s never forgotten how nice she was to him.“My favorite moments on the road are the ones where I can connect with people like @anitascipio,” -year-old Will told his Instagram followers before he walked in to the station to give her a hug.In the days before social media, someone who worked at his record company Sony told me that whenever he was in town, Will would tour the building, from post room to boardroom, giving time to everyone.He’s that rare creature, a star on screen and off.Some of today’s petulant slebs should watch and learn.FORMER psychiatric nurse Susan Evans is launching a landmark legal case to challenge consent issues around the provision of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for under-s.She argues that children should be protected from “experimental” and “invasive medical treatment”, not least because “some children are referred despite having autism, being homosexual or suffering some form of trauma or sexual abuse”.Speaking on Radio , she added that children as young as nine were being asked to consent “to a completely experimental treatment for which long-term consequences are not known”.But gender ersity advocates warn that “a loss to trans youth is a loss to all”.Time will tell the outcome of her case but, meanwhile, in unrelated comments, I note that the actor Rupert Everett says he spent most of his early childhood wanting “to be a girl”.He adored his mother, aunt and grandmother, didn’t like men, and adds: “I loved necklaces and bras and all those kinds of things.”Then, when he reached , he “didn’t want to be a girl any more. I really enjoyed being a homosexual”.The case in point, perhaps, for treading very carefully indeed with pre-teens.POLICE officers will be required to have degrees from this year – a move that could remove , recruits from the front line while they complete their studies.Sigh. Really When it comes to tackling crime on our streets, the majority of us want someone on our side who possesses instinct, courage and common sense.Which you either have or don’t regardless of qualications.NATURISTS John and Donna Price have moved from Kent to Lincolnshire for more privacy because they like to barbecue in the nude.“I love a flambeed banana,” says Donna, .Oooer.Aren’t our AEs under enough pressure Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark huawei 5g network
story: This is a company that has brought us the technology of an iPhone but at a fraction of the cost.I am no protectionist and I don’t fear the Chinese.When it comes to selling us consumer goods, I am more than happy to welcome China’s companies into the country to compete with British, European or US-made products.But it is a very dferent matter when it comes to allowing a Chinese company to build Britain’s next- generation broadband network — with all the security issues that raises.Unbelievably, the Government is seriously considering doing just this.Yesterday, the Prime Minister — who is due to make a decision next month on whether to award Huawei a contract to build parts of Britain’s G network — indicated that he is inclined to give the company the nod.Critics, he said, needed to suggest which other company ought to be allowed to do the work.I am sorryI am a little ignorant on this point. While I have bought several mobile phones, I have never gone shopping for an entire telecoms network.But surely there must be other potential contractors. Don’t we have a telecoms industry of our own It doesn’t say much for the Government’s privatisation of BTit is not in the running for this sort of work.What about our own Vodafone, which I thought was one of the world leaders in mobile phone technology Evendepriving Huawei of the work meant we had to wait a little longer or pay a little extra to download a movie to our phones, that would surely be a reasonable price to pay for protecting national security.And national security policy really is at stake.Yesterday the US reaffirmed that allowing Huawei to build our G network — even parts of it which are deemed to be low- risk — would be “madness” and could compromise the willingness of the US to share vital intelligence with Britain in future.This didn’t come in one of Donald Trump’s notorious am tweets but from officials working for Matt Pottinger, the US deputy national security adviser, and Robert Blair, special representative for international telecommunications policy.That they took the trouble to visit London to warn of the dangers we could be getting ourselves into ought to be seen as a red flag on Huawei’s involvement in our G network.Surely, the importance of being able to share intelligence with our most important ally should rank above pure considerations of cost.Australia has already blocked the Chinese firm from its G network.Yet here, the head of MI Sir Andrew Parker said he had “no reason” to think Britain’s intelligence partnership with the US would sufferinvolvement from the Chinese firm was given the green light.But Defence Secretary Ben Wallace underlined at the weekend that the US administration has threatened to cut off some intelligenceBritain approves Huawei’s involvement in G.He said: “Those things will be taken into account when the Government collectively decides to make a decision on it.”Our own Government — as it has been doing since Theresa May’s day — insists that only parts of the G contract would be awarded to Huawei.It would not be allowed to work on security-critical areas.But that isn’t good enough. Such is the complexity of modern telecommunications networks that it would be impossible to be sure that systems installed in one part of the network were not enabling data to be obtained from another.Whoever designs and builds a telecommunications system gains the power to interfere with it, or even switch it off, should it feel inclined.Of course, with modern communications a huge amount of damage can be done from afar.Evenwe are confident our broadband network is secure now, we can’t be certain that would remain the case.A company which installs a telecommunications network will necessarily continue to be involved in maintaining and upgrading the network it had designed and installed.We have to be absolutely sure the network is not being used for some underhand purpose.Huawei denies that it is controlled by the Chinese state, and has threatened to sue commentators in France whom it alleges have made that claim.But the precise relationship between Huawei and the Chinese state is hardly the point.What is certain is that China is not a democracy and there is always going to be a security issue when it comes to involving its industrial giants in sensitive work here.We would not allow a Chinese company, say, to build fighter jets for the RAF or to construct our radar defence system.This kind of work is rightly the preserve of contractors on whom we can rely totally, even in times of international conflict.Such is the importance of telecommunications in military and civil defence that we now have to think of mobile networks in the same light.The Government has been warning for years that cyber warfare is the big coming threat.In  it published a Strategic Defence Review which defined cyber attack as a “Tier One” threat alongside terrorism.Last November, the US and Taiwanese held a joint exercise in fending off a major cyber attack on Taiwan.At the time the Taiwanese Cyber Security Agency said it was the subject of an astonishing million cyber attacks every month, half of which came from the Chinese mainland.So why, then, is our own Government even considering commissioning a Chinese company to install a telecommunications network Of course, Boris Johnson is right to make it clear he is not Donald Trump’s poodle.We don’t have to take notice of everything the Americans say, on defence, trade or anything .But when it comes to our closest ally warning us that it might not want to share intelligence with us in futurewe let a Chinese company build our G network, we very much do need to take notice.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP title: eu trade deal fishing rights
story: Eurocrats hardened their position on demanding continued access to our waters after Boris Johnson vowed not to extend the transition period beyond December .The EU said talks on fisheries will now have a “direct link” to thrashing out tarf and quota free trade on goods.Previously, the EU had stated access for its vessels would be secured “within the context of the overall economic partnership”.But Mr Johnson’s insistence the UK will quit the transition come what may at the end of this year has sparked concern in Brussels.Eurocrats believe only a “bare bones” trade deal on goods will be done by then and want to play hardball over fishing for maximum leverage.In a briefing to EU diplomats, Michel Barnier’s team said any deal on “reciprocal” access would be of “unprecedented scale and scope”.The pact would include agreements on quotas that European fishermen can land in our waters and a clause to protect their livelihoods.EU negotiators want to get it done by July  this year — the date by which the UK must say whether or not it plans to extend the transition.EU trade chief Phil Hogan has suggested fishing rights may be secured in a “trade-off” with the UK over market access for the City of London.Eurocrats argue access for EU boats cannot be separated from tarf-free terms for British fish products on EU markets.The PM has vowed to take back control of UK fishing waters when the transition period ends.Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen warned the PM he wont be able to “have his cake and eat it” in trade talks. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The shock move is seen as part of Putins efforts to carve out a new position of power for himself to stay at the helm after his current term as president ends in .It was announced today by the president’s right-hand man, PM Dmitry Medvedev, who said it would give Putin room to carry out the changes he wants to make to the constitution.The unexpected revelation came shortly after Putin proposed a nationwide vote on sweeping changes that he said would sht power from the presidency to parliament.It is feared the move will create a powerful new position for Putin to step into once his presidency ends.The changes would likely weaken his successor and while allowing him to hold the real power as PM -with no term limits.The announcement means Russia will also get a new prime minister.Possible candidates include Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, Maxim Oreshkin, the economy minister, or Alexander Novak, the energy minister.Medvedev made the announcement on state TV sitting next to Putin who thanked Medvedev, a close ally, for his work.The president said Medvedev will now take on a new job as deputy head of Russias Security Council, which Putin chairs.Medvedev, a longtime pal of Putins, has served as Russias PM since .He spent four years before that as president in -, becoming a placeholder when Putin had to switch into the PMs office because of constitutional term limits on the presidency.Medvedev then obediently stepped down after just one term as president and let Putin reclaim the top job.The move was widely seen as cynical political manoeuvring and triggered massive protests in MoscowPutin asked for the outgoing government to remain at work until a new government was appointed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry wake up think what have i done liddle
story: But that should surely be a fairly simple matter. Harry and Meghan have said they wish to be “independent”. A lot of time has been spent working out how that independence can be achieved.Well, here’s the thing. I have a cunning plan for the Sussexes as to how they might be “independent”.What you need to do is get something called a “job”.If you get one of those they give you money which you can use to buy things — a house, some Pot Noodles, a Hot Wheels car racing set — anything, really, within reason.  Remarkable, isn’t it It probably wouldn’t pay for the £million Canadian mansion Meghan is holed up in right now — but they can always ponce a few freebies off their mega-rich friends.It might not quite cover the legal costs Meghan may incur from her upcoming court case. She’s suing a newspaper and her dad is set to testy AGAINST her.You have to say she has a knack, this lass, of getting on the wrong side of quite a few people.I think it’s fair to guess that the Royal Family are not entirely happy with her right now. So she’s hacked off her new family much as she’s hacked off her own one.It’s no huge surprise they’re both heading off to “Canada” .Meghan seems not to like the UK very much. She doesn’t spend much time in it and my suspicion is that the local people haven’t entirely taken to her.We had a bit of time for Harry, once. He seemed an amiably thick rugger-bugger with a mischievous sense of humour. Not any more, sadly.He seems to spend half of his time crying. And he also seems to have swallowed whole the air-headed, ultra-woke, touchy-feely drivel his we has imported from the United States.Still, we were happy to spend an extortionate sum doing up their “cottage” with the most expensive materials money could buy. And we were delighted to see photographs of young Archie — once we were allowed to by madam.For someone who dislikes the starchy formality of the Royal Family, Meghan displays quite a few airs and graces, doesn’t she Hates being photographed and gets her bullying minders to stop people taking snaps. Loves being photographed when she’s promoting herself or her vacuous ideas.But hey, they love each other and that’s the important thing.Let them move to Canada or LA, where they can jabber to each other about climate change and how everyone who doesn’t like her is racist, until the cows come home.But let them do it entirely independently. No money from the Duchy of Cornwall Estate. No royal stipend. No security staff paid for by the taxpayers, either here or there.Let them be truly independent, which is what they seem to wish for.Maybe they’ll find it liberating. Or maybe in a year or two Prince Harry will wake up and think: Crikey, what have I done.DO you remember when you first had a McDonald’s  I remember very well. I was  and had just come down to London from Middlesbrough.My girlfriend told me about these wonderful things called Big Macs. I tried one – couldn’t believe how delicious it was. So I bought another, and then another.Stood there, stuffing my fat face, eyes wide with delight.As the years go by, the pleasure diminishes a little – there’s nothing better than tasting something delicious for the first time.So lucky, lucky people of Rutland. Lovely bunch, footballers, aren’t they And was all of this sanctioned by the supposedly progressive and right-on manager, Pep Guardiola “That was not what I meant, Senor Aguero, when I said you had to get in the box more often.” HERE is yet another Re-moaner head case for you. Liberal Democrat peer Lord Greaves.He has said he fears Britain will be reminiscent of Nazi Germany when we finally leave the European Union. And sending snap-shots of their genitals to -year-old men who are pretending to be teenagers.THERE was a rather cheering plan to ring out the church bells across the land to mark our escape from the European Union at the end of the month.But a bunch of bishops have said we shouldn’t do that because the bells should only be used to summon the faithful to worship.With the greatest of respect, your reverend, b*****ks. You can tell it’s nothing to do with that by their comments.One said: “Two thirds of the population never voted for Brexit in the first place. It’s deeply isive to ring church bells for something like this.”Yeah, Bish – we have a habit in this country of only counting the votes of people who voted, you mimsy frock-wearing halfwit.Another said: “I think we should be ringing bells on February , not to celebrate Brexit but to call people together to pray for our nation at this critical time.”Ah, go shove your bells up your cassock, you miserable Remoaner God-bothering bores.A UKRAINIAN bloke woke up one morning to discover a large metal nut around his old fella.His we had placed it there during the night to stop him shagging other women. title: prince harry meghan markle not welcome in canada

although a riddle over who actually owns it has deepened as a controversial mining tycoon denied it was his.The couple will now go through a period of transition that will see them create a new le as a young family and spend time in both Canada and the UK.The Queen said she was “entirely supportive of Harry and Meghan’s desire to create a new le as a young family”.The summit, which took almost four hours, took place between the Queen, Prince Charles, and brothers William and Harry.The fine detail of the agreement — especially the controversial issue of who will fund the couple’s new le — will be thrashed out over the next few days.But The Globe and Mail blasted: “[Canada’s] unique monarchy, and its delicate yet essential place in our constitutional system, means that a royal resident — the Prince is sixth in the line of succession — is not something that Canada can allow.“A royal living in this country does not accord with the long-standing nature of the relationship between Canada and Britain, and Canada and the Crown.“Though Canada borrowed from Britain, it isn’t Britain and never was. title: big ben must chime for brexit the miserabilists and pessimists cannot get their way
story: As Britain throws off the shackles of rule by the European Union, a new era of national freedom beckons.The arrival of British independence, after nearly half a century of Brussels domination, is a moment for profound celebration.And there could be no more appropriate way to mark this historic milestone than a series of chimes from the mighty bell that is Big Ben.For the landmark is a shining symbol of both British nationhood and our parliamentary democracy.Since its completion in , the clock tower synonymous with its famous bell has become a cultural icon, renowned across the world.At a height of ft, its majestic beauty epitomises the greatness of our country. The distinctive peal from its massive, .-ton bell is a part of the soundtrack of our public le.But sadly, it now seems likely that the advent of Brexit will be met by silence from Big Ben.If the parliamentary authorities have their way, no sound will echo from the clock tower on that momentous night.Since , the building has been undergoing a major renovation programme, including the installation of a lt, resurfacing of the dials, and restoration of the clock mechanism.According to the House of Commons Commission, which oversees the Westminster estate, the cost of interrupting this work to enable Big Ben to chime for Brexit would be more than £,.We are told this huge bill arises because of the need to install a temporary floor in the belfry to support the chiming equipment — as well as the impact of delays, for up to four weeks, in the renovation project.In the view of pessimistic officialdom, the whole idea of the Brexit chimes is just too expensive.As Sir Lindsay Hoyle, the new Speaker of the Commons, put it this week, “You are talking about £, a bong.”The arch-Remainers have, predictably, seized on the problem with glee.For them, the entire business is just like Brexit itself — a pointless, costly distraction.That negativity is shared by large parts of the civil service and Westminster establishment.Viewing Brexit with horror, they seek to prevent any inspirational commemoration of the event.So the supposed heavy costs give them the perfect excuse to do nothing, just as they used bureaucratic stalemate to thwart Brexit for years.Indeed, the Big Ben dficulty can be seen as ato Project Fear, once more, where dire financial warnings are deployed to frighten the public into inaction.But the British people did not give in to Project Fear , and they should not be cowered by more alarmism this time.The shrill negative voice of Remainers had dominated for too long.After the decisive General Election last month, that is the noise that should be hushed, not the chimes of Big Ben.Expressions of national pride are a force for benevolence and unity, as we witnessed in the recent cricket World Cup triumph.Despite all the Remainer gloom, there is a tremendous yearning to celebrate British-ness.That spirit can also be seen in the broad popular support for the idea of a new Festival of Britain, in , to extol the values of our nation.Once again, just as with their negativity over Big Ben, the pro-EU brigade sneered at the concept as nothing more than a Festival of Brexit, which could only enshrine entrenched isions.But in reality, just like the successful post-war Festival of Britain in , the  Festival could achieve the very opposite, by enabling us to reconnect with our identity, heritage and future.The same can be true of the Brexit chimes on January . It can be an occasion for joy and openness, not misery and fearfulness.Boris Johnson’s suggestion that the £, bill could be met by an appeal to the public is being scuppered by senior officials.In his usual inimitable style, Boris had asked for crowd-funding citizens to “bung a bob for a Big Ben bong”. There were signs the campaign could be taking off.The passionate Euro-sceptic MP Mark Francois pledged £,, while there was also speculation that millionaires such as Lord Ashcroft and Wetherspoon pub chain boss Tim Martin could make large donations.Officials yesterday said there was “no legal basis” for using public donations. So why shouldn’t the Government chip in  After all, the state is used to bankrolling exceptional national events, often at a far bigger cost.A reported £million went on Meghan and Harry’s wedding in .Most of that was swallowed up by security, but £, alone went on her bridal dress — which is not far off the cost of the Big Ben bongs.Similarly, the bill for the chimes is barely a quarter of the more than £million estimated to be spent on the official London fireworks display on New Year’s Eve.But before any money is handed over by the public or Treasury, the huge potential bill — £, to get the bell to chime, plus the £, cost of delays to the tower’s repair — must be challenged.In all kinds of major projects, because of weak management, contractors and consultants often expand the budgets for their own interests.We have seen that process with the HS rail link, now on course to cost over £billion, while even with the renovation of Big Ben the project’s bill has risen from an original £million to £million.On Tuesday night, one former project manager in Parliament said the estimate for the chimes had been absurdly inflated.“I cannot believe the costs you’re talking about,” he told LBC radio.The can-do, anti-establishment outlook ensured the victory of Brexit. With the same imagination and drive, the campaign for the Big Ben chimes can succeed.In fact, it could be the cue for a string of other celeb-rations across our land on January , like bonfires, fire-work displays or big screen-ings in city squares.But at the centre of it all has to be the Westminster clock tower. As Nigel Farage put it, “If Big Ben doesn’t sound, our country looks like a joke.”The miserabilists and pessimists must not get their way.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: manchester grooming gangs would been
story: NewsopinionThe Manchester grooming gangs would have been stamped outtheir victims were someone other than poor young girlsRace and religion has been blamed for systematic child abuse, but the creation of an underclass of the "undeserving poor" means they are still getting away with itShareByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf  pensioners from Tunbridge Wells had been raped in plain sight of their carers, heads would roll. If  grammar school boys,  besuited City workers,  MPs or  police officers were stalked for years by a gang of sex abusers, it would cause legal and social upheaval.  But  poor girls from south Manchester  Girls who were poor, born to parents who could not look after them, in care, with no hope, no way out, and no prospects, girls who seem pre-destined for a le of abuse, crime, and addiction  Well, letaposs not be too hasty, lads. We donapost want to make Rusholme look bad. We donapost want to put too much pressure on the police. We have enough problems with race. These girls arenapost angels. And there might be political concerns. Letaposs just agree itaposs all very sad and shut down the investigation because we know all about it, now.The report into the Manchester grooming scandal which was published yesterday quotes one detective who helped arrest and charge a rapist who was not Asian. He said: It was a prosperous middle-class area, and they were well-to-do kids. They werenapost from the original tranche of children that were in childrenaposs homes... we were told to try and get other ethnicities.If you raped a rich kid, you got nicked. And coppers werenapost told to catch rapists. They were told to tick boxes. In Rusholme, Rotherham, Peterborough, Oxford, Rochdale, Bristol, Telford, Newcastle, Aylesbury, Huddersfield, and Keighley, the children who should be most protected by the state were hung out to dry by servants of that state. The authorities ignored, covered up, and swept under the carpet hundreds,not thousands, of horrying crimes.Many tried, and failed, to get their managers to act when girls were injected with drugs, groomed, raped, beaten, made pregnant, given abortions, and had their children taken away. But all too often, the authorities were wilfully-blind partners in the abuse. This is what happens, when you politicise the police with locally-elected crime commissioners. When chief constables get too pally with council leaders. When social workers are blamed for not doing the things politicians stop them doing. Well-funded childrenaposs services look after children. Police officers who donapost care for politics chase criminals of all races. And an NHS with the time and staff to track, counsel and help the most dficult people it has to deal with can link up with other services to see the full picture, not just the black eye. Butyouaposre one of the unlucky ones, youaposre on your own. Five years ago, Professor Alexis Jayaposs report into child sex abuse in Rotherham found that white and Asian girls were victims of men who were of Pakistani, Kosovan and Kurdish heritage. They were mostly Muslim, but included other races and faiths too. White victims were more likely to come forward, but were not treated fairly because of officials contemptuous about race, class and gender.The rapists told their victims - which included Sikh, Hindu and Muslim girls - they were targeted because they were the wrong sort of girl. And everyone seems to have taken the rapists at their word. The bigger truth is they were targeted because they didnapost matter. Black or white, they were poor. They were girls. And they didnapost matter to their rapists, the police, or the politicians.  When Victoria Agoglia died of an overdose aged , the coroner recorded a narrative verdict saying she was known to grant sexual favours to men infor drugs.Two months before her death, Victoria had reported that she was being raped and injected with heroin by an older man. No effort - none - was made to help her. And even so, a coroner said her rape was a favour she had granted. Every rapist picks someone they can control. Someone who wonapost be believed. And what better victim than a kid in care, with track marks on her arms. Britain has created a new underclass. People who, more than a century ago, were called the undeserving poor, people who made their own problems and did not observe the rules of dress, work and manners that the God-fearing, hard-working poor did.  The Victorians changed their minds about the poor, eventually. Journalists exposed the scandal of children sold into prostitution, laws were changed, slums were cleared, living standards improved. When the boom of the s was replaced by the Great Depression and everyone feared the breadline, moves began for the welfare state that was introduced only after two world wars had destroyed our class barriers.A century on, weaposve built those barriers again.There are places only some sorts of people live, eat, and work. They get less money spent on them. The streets are not swept as often. The landlords go unchecked. The schools are expected to be bad.It is those places who bred the rapists, and their victims. They created ignorance, otherness, and a world with dferent rules. Racism of all sorts festered, to the point that men of all faiths believed poor girls were easy meat, and the rest believed it was just what men like them did.The same places have bred county lines drug dealers, kne gangs, and other socially-expensive forms of misery. This underclass consists of hundreds of thousands of people, victims and criminals, and untold thousands of children who are still being raped.  Lessons were learned after the Rotherham scandal was first exposed in . They were learned again when a gang was jailed in , in  in Rochdale and the House of Commons, in  after the Jay report and again in  and , after  men and  women were convicted. But their crimes dated back to the s. The council knew of them in the s. Predominantly-male local officials, whose own families were unlikely to be victims, ignored it all and decided it was more important they got re-elected.The lessons learned are usually that victims must have their crimes prosecuted. Itaposs all but useless for most vulnerable children, who distrust the authorities, who are kept apart, addicted, or who see no way out. A prosecution makes bugger all dference to the basic problem which is that we now asks ourselves who deserves justice, and who does not.  To the short-sighted, Islam is to blame, or takeaway owners, or those of Pakistani origin. To others, itaposs the state, the namby-pamby social workers, or Labour councillors who didnapost want to upset their voting base.Very few think this is down to all of us. Since the s when this pattern of abuse began, we have ided our nation into people who deserve to do well, and those who donapost. People who work hard, and those on benefits. Those we want to live next door to, and those we donapost.We have not noticed it, but all the evidence shows we have also ided ourselves into people who deserve to be victims, and those who deserve a police investigation. Those who deserve hope, and those doomed to hopelessness. This wound on our soft underbelly will kill us, unless it is disinfected. The people most in need of help, of good schools, of education, and the full attention of all the authorities, must get it - and at the expense of those who can manage without it. The lessons have not been learned. Tough sentences will not stop further offences. Someone like Victoria is being raped, today, not because of race or religion but because more than one person has decided that child deserves to be raped. The only way to stop it is to admit that weaposd all be in that underclass, with a little bad luck. And tell our leaders that no-one deserves to be stuck in it.

title: a special feel about scottish cup mcpake
story: Dundee manager James McPake admits there is “a special feel” about Dens Park this week as the Scottish Cup comes around.The Dark Blues’ recent record in the competition hasn’t had too many high points but that isn’t stopping James looking forward to enjoying his first taste of the competition as a manager.As a player, he scored in a Scottish Cup Final defeat while playing for Hibs and is keen for his players to enjoy a similar run in the competition under his watch as boss.He said: “It is the old cliche, ‘the romance of the Scottish Cup’ but there is a special feel to it.“Motherwell are expected to come here and win as they are the Premiership club but we will have a right go and we can’t wait for it.“We will be facing an opposition that’s dferent from what we normally face in terms of they will come here with a real attacking threat.“The only other two teams who have done that this season are Dundee United and Ayr United.“Motherwell will be the same –they will just come out and have a right go like they do when they go to the likes of Celtic Park.“That’s the way they play. I like watching them when they go forward but we need to find a way to hurt them with our style of play as well.“It should be a good game for people to watch.”Saturday’s visitors Motherwell have enjoyed an impressive season in the top flight, sitting in the best-of-the-rest position in third behind the runaway top two of Rangers and Celtic.Stephen Robinson has been in charge at Fir Park for almost three years now and has overseen an upwards trajectory of the club.Dens boss James, though, isn’t shocked to see the Steelmen flying high this term, however.He added: “No, it hasn’t surprised me.“You can see why the manager has been successful with his recruitment and the way they play.“They can beat any team in that league from what I’ve seen of them this season.”This season is Motherwell’s th in the top-flight after last playing in the second tier in .And that sort of longevity at the top table of Scottish football is something Dundee should be enjoying, according to their manager. vw, px"  James added: “They have been in that league for as long as I can remember.“I said this at the start of the season – five years isn’t long enough for a club like ours to be in the Premiership .“People were saying we had a good run at it but no we didn’t.“We should be in it every year – as should our neighbours.“When you look at Scottish football, you want the derbies.“It was horrible when Hearts and Hibs weren’t in the same league so you didn’t have the Edinburgh derbies and it was the same when Rangers and Celtic weren’t in the same league.“The Dundee one is all right just now because we are both in the Championship.“But, for me, you want the better games in your top league.“But going back to that question, yes, we want to be a club that can sustain a position in the top league for  years or beyond.“Looking back at Motherwell, to be there from  is a long time staying in a league.“We did five – it is not enough.“We need to get back up and stay there.“The problem is, there are loads of teams saying that.“Not many can do it so credit to Motherwell.”Kick off on Saturday is .pm at Dens Park with the match shown live on BBC Scotland.

title: dens gaffer we wont be bullied
story: James McPake admits there has been “loads of interest” in attacking midfielder Josh Todd.However, the Dundee boss won’t be allowing any player to leave unless he gets players in the door first.And he insists the club won’t “be bullied” into paying over the odds for players.The Tele revealed this week Greenock Morton and Falkirk had expressed interest in the -year-old former Queen of the South man.James said: “There is loads of interest in Josh.“I have had a few phone calls about him.“But nothing will happen until I sit down and have a proper conversation with him.“He did great in a bounce game on Tuesday and attitude-wise he has been great.“He doesn’t look like a player who wants to leave.“Maybe he has been saying that he has not been getting the game time but he needs to ask himself why that’s the case.“Can he get himself into the team or is he looking to go where  I don’t know. Anyway, nobody will be going anywhere unless I get someone in.”The Dens gaffer admits that hasn’t been easy to do, however.The Dark Blues have been heavily linked with a move to bring Craig Wighton back to the club as well as St Johnstone midfielder Ross Callachan, with a deal for the latter apparently rubber stamped.“We are trying to get people in but it is proving to be dficult,” added James.“I can see now why, when the question is asked about this transfer window, people say it’s more dficult to deal in.“It is a lot harder and teams are digging their heels in a lot more.Teams are trying to bully us because it’s Dundee. It beggars belief.#Lesley goes online every month to pay her council tax, which is in the tax band D and  costs her an annual £..She said: #Obviously somewhere along the line I have only paid them £..#I am quite happy to accept that I have paid £ too little and will pay up # that#s not the issue here.#It obviously wasn#t intentional on my part but to go to the  bother and expense of sending out a letter seem way over the top.# vw, px"  Lesley said that just to make a point she plans to head to DCC herself with £ worth of one pennies to pay the debt.She said: #I#m sufficiently annoyed and upset at this that they will get their money but I plan to count it out to them one penny at a time.#Someone even suggested that I  just pay up in instalments but maybe that#s taking it a little too far.#A spokesman for Dundee City Council said: “The council has a duty to collect Council Tax irrespective of the amount that is due, and the cost to issue a bill in this case is much less than the sum being collected.“The most efficient and cost effective way to collect Council Tax is to set up a Direct Debit, this can be done online at www.dundeecity.gov.uk ct-dd#

title: mccall shanks could play for any team in scotland
story: Partick Thistle boss Ian McCall reckons Lawrence Shankland could play for any team in Scotland, amid speculation Celtic are monitoring the Dundee United hitman.McCall was Shankland’s gaffer at Ayr United and watched on as he scored a perfect hat-trick to help United down his Thistle side - at Firhill on Saturday .And McCall wasn’t the only onlooker of note, with scouts from the Scottish champions and English Championship outfit Queens Park Rangers reportedly in attendance in Glasgow to watch the Scotland star at the weekend.Former Tangerines manager McCall also expressed his frustration as his side weren’t able to capitalise on an opening  minutes where they performed well.“For the first half-an-hour that was the best we’ve played at Firhill, we were terric,” he said.“We should’ve been ahead in the game but when you pick a very attacking team, and we were a bit hamstrung so we had to go with that, then it makes it a bit harder when you don’t get the first goal.“In the second half we were really poor and they’ve got a centre forward that can play for any team in Scotland and he’s playing in the Championship.“It was tough going in the second half for our fans.”McCall added: “We’ve been on a good run, that’s only our third loss in  games but it’s a sore one because we were at Firhill.“We wanted to have a real go, make it a competitive game but the two goals in the last five or six minutes in the first half killed it for us.“We tried to change it but it didn’t happen, it was a sore day in the second half.”

title: partick thistle 1 4 dundee united perfect hat trick from shankland sends utd 17 clear
story: Dundee United went  points clear at the top of the Championship as a perfect hat-trick from Lawrence Shankland sent them on their way to aShankland opened the scoring at Firhill with a header on  minutes, with strikes on either foot coming in the second half after Adrian Sporle had made it - on the stroke of half-time.Kenny Miller pulled a late goal back for the Jags but three points means the Tangerines are now  points clear of Inverness at the top of the Championship.United showed two changes from last weekend#s win at Queen of the South with captain Mark Reynolds and new boy Dillon Powers coming in for his debut in place of Jamie Robson and Calum Butcher.Partick had an early penalty shout for handball but referee Willie Collum waved away the claims and instead pointed for a corner.Lawrence Shankland headed straight at Scott Fox in the home goal from a deep Nicky Clark free-kick moments later as the game began to settle down.Benjamin Siegrist in the United net had the simplest of saves from James Penrice on  minutes before Declan Glass dragged a shot wide up the other end.The cut-up pitch, due to the wet conditions in Glasgow, saw much of the build-up from both teams bogged down but, of the good football on show, it was the Terrors with the lion#s share.Glass troubled Fox again on  minutes with a dipping, bouncing effort. However, the best chance of the opening half hour was the Jags#.A lung-busting run from Dario Zanatta nearly paid idends for the hosts but Siegrist#s legs foiled the Canadian inside the penalty area.Paul Watson saw a header drt wide from a Clark delivery before Shankland teed up Glass, only for the -year-old to fire wide once again.Zanatta once more came close on  minutes, this time glancing a Joe Cardle delivery towards goal but into the grateful arms of Siegrist.Just a minute later, the Tangerines No  was again the thorn in Thistle#s side.On his own in the six-yard box, Kenny Miller picked up on Zanatta#s cross only for the big Swiss keeper to pull off a wonder save to deny Miller from close range.Clark forced Fox into action with an audacious effort from some  yards before the former Dundee keeper halted Shankland close in.However, moments later, Shanks wasn#t to be denied his nd United goal of the season.From a Clark corner, the Scotland star had the freedom of the Thistle box to guide a header beyond a helpless Fox for - on  minutes.And Shankland was at the heart of United#s second. Picking up on the ball in the middle of the Partick half, he drove forward and slipped in Glass.The United kid#s cross-cum-shot found Adrian Sporle with the simplest of tasks to tap home unopposed for his first league goal for the club.After a frenetic first period, the second  took a while to get going but it was Ian McCall#s side on the front foot.Just before the hour-mark, the impressive Reece Cole made a powerful run into the box before his effort won the Jags a corner.However, it was United who got the scoring under way in the second half and took control with the first chance of note in the period.And it was that man Shankland again as he went on a terric -yard solo run into the Partick box before calmly slotting beyond Fox for his second of the afternoon and the Terrors# third.Peter Pawlett completed his comeback from injury on  minutes when he replaced Paul Watson.And, just a minute later, his first involvement in the game was to tee up Shankland for his third, completing a perfect hat-trick by thundering a left-foot drive into the top corner to send the ,-strong visiting support wild.One of few worries for United on the afternoon came on  minutes when Clark had to limp off injured, to be replaced by Adam King.Miller netted a late consolation for Thistle on  minutes but Robbie Neilson#s men took all the points and another step towards sealing the title.Partick Thistle XI : FoxWilliamson , Saunders, O#Ware , Penrice Cardle , Bannigan, Cole, Zanatta Jones , Miller.Subs not used: Sneddon , Harkins, Slater and Mansell.Dundee United XI : SiegristSmith, Watson , Connolly, ReynoldsPowers Appere, Glass , Clark , Sporle Shankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Sow, Stanton and Freeman.Referee: Willie Collum.Att: , .

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: refurbished statue is back in rightful place in north east town centre
story: A refurbished statue which looks out across a north-east town centre has been painstakingly ed home.The repaired effigy of Alexander Fraser, the th Lord Saltoun, sat above the door of the council chambers on Fraserburgh’s Saltoun Square since .But the harsh weather took its toll and left the statue without a face. vw, px"  As part of a near-£ million regeneration scheme in Fraserburgh the figurine was removed, and for the last few months, stone conservator Karolina Allan has been trying to give him a new look.With the work complete, the statue has been hoisted back into its original home, which will now be known as the Faithlie Centre.The former council chamber will be an enterprise centre to help start-up businesses as part of a £.m revamp.Specialist teams were in Fraserburgh yesterday to supervise the heavy stone statue being lted into place.Banff and Buchan area committee vice-chairman Mike Roy said it was “exciting” the effiguy had been ed to its “rightful place”.He added: “Karolina’s excellent work has transformed the statue and is a great symbol of the detailed work and traditional skills being used bring this historic building back into use.“We are all very much looking forward to the Faithlie Centre becoming a hub of local activity once again.” vw, px"  Brian Topping, chairman of the Fraserburgh Regeneration Development Partnership, said he was pleased to see progress on part of the major project for the town was moving forward.He said: “Bringing the Faithlie Centre back into use is a major part of the regeneration work currently taking place in Fraserburgh, and I am sure everybody will pleased to see Lord Saltoun overlooking the square once again.“The investment in the town will bring new and improved opportunities for Aberdeenshire Council, our partners and the public and this marks a great start for the year ahead.”Alexander Fraser was known as the “Waterloo Saltoun” after fighting in the Napoleonic Wars.The statue was created by London-based sculptor Edward Stephen and arrived in , six years after Lord Saltoun died.
