title: Author spends decade visiting churches
story: A CO Down artist has written about a personal spiritual journey which took her to every church in Belfast.Bronagh Lawson spent ten years visiting hundreds of churches throughout the city, as well as some closer to home. The result is Belfast: City of Light, a new book in which she shares her experiences and asks some pertinent questions on matters of faith and beliefs.Bronagh began her journey as a non-churchgoer. Now, she says she is a dferent person.ldquoI did not set out to go on this journey or write this book, but simply started to follow an artistic thread like many artists over the centuries before me, she remarked. ldquoThe thread became so compelling and extraordinary that I eventually felt destined to write it down.Born in Newtownards in  to Frances and Paddy Lawson, who had ed to Belfast to oversee the design and building of the Ulster Museum, Bronagh spent her first two years on the Upper Newtownards Road in Belfast with her three older sisters, before moving to Portaferry in  and later to Strangford.Educated at Down High School, in  she attended art college in Bristol and then gained a first class degree in textiles fashion at Winchester School of Art, Hampshire. Moving to London on graduation, she won a Fulbright scholarship and attended Parsons School of Design in New York.Bronagh sometimes visited Northern Ireland and despaired. Prior to the end of the Troubles she spent time as a participant on ious cross-community development programmes before deciding to use her creativity in a dferent way.For  years she set up and ran cross-border, cross-community development programmes mostly within the enterprise sector in interfaceareas of Belfast. At the same time she explored her own upbringing during the Troubles and heard many stories from people in Belfast of experience she only saw on TV growing up and often switched off in horror.She spent three years based in North Belfast, between the republican New Lodge and loyalist Tigers Bay areas. Walking into work one day she collapsed. She had become incapable of processing the traumas that people living in some of most deprived areas of Europe were enduring on a daily basis.She found herself coming back to her original training as an artist and started a journey towards her own healing by going to church.Bronagh says she asked herself a lot of questions as she attended Protestant and Catholic services in Belfast and beyond.She says: ldquoWhatinstead of listening to the continuous repeated stories of Protestant vs Catholic in Belfast, an inidual had first-hand experience of visiting every church in the city for a service, simply looking and listening when going to each one ldquoWhat would they see and hear  As a non-church goer starting out on this journey, how would you feel ten years later  What is going on in churches in contemporary Belfast  How might this open-minded curiosity inform the continuous shting conversation about the city that I call home Belfast: City of Light costs pound and is available online at lulu. It is also available locally at Kevin Ogrsquos shop in Strangford..prettyPhoto

title: Bronagh loses over eight stone during incredible year
story: IF yoursquod love to slim down and feel better about yourself in , then please read about a young lady who made  an exceptional year.Bronagh OrsquoNeill lost eight stones and eight-and-a-half pounds in just  months with the help of Slimming World.Itrsquos crazy to think that this time last year Bronagh wasnrsquot even a Slimming World member. She had no idea the food optimising plan was so easy, nor did she realise how good she could feel from the inside out just by losing weight.Slimming World has five decades of experience helping millions of people to lose weight and also has a fun calendar of celebrations planned throughout the year.Bronagh says: ldquoWhile I was looking forward to Christmas  I knew it would be very dferent to the previous year.ldquoAfter making many changes in my lestyle in the last  months with food and exercise I knew Christmas was the time that would put me to the test.Bronagh says she is looking forward to new members joining her Slimming World group and seeing them discover that they can lose weight without feeling hungry or deprived.However,  is also going to be a special year for Bronagh. Shersquos getting married and because shersquos on target with her weight loss itrsquos going to be extra memorable.ldquoI love the principles of Slimming World and the promise of weight loss with no hunger, no judgment and freedom from guilt. Thatrsquos exactly what I needed to hear to get me started, she remarked.Slimming Worldrsquos food optimising eating plan is based foods that are best at satisfying your appetite and have the fewest calories per gramme.You learn how to make healthy choices, lose weight and keep the weight off without feeling hungry.Therersquos no such thing as a lsquoquick fixrsquo when it comes to losing weight and Slimming World has always offered sustainable, long-term weight loss, so itrsquos definitely the best choice for anyone wanting to get slim for le this January mdash and to have a great time in the process..prettyPhoto

title: Call to begin work on Ballynahinch bypass
story: THE re-establishment of the Stormont Executive has led to fresh calls for work to start on Ballynahinchrsquos proposed multi-million pound bypass.Newly appointed Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon is being urged to signal the start of construction work on the scheme which is estimated to cost in excess of poundm.South Down MP Chris Hazzard mdash a former roads minister in a previous Executive who signed off the eagerly-awaited bypass in December  mdash has written to Ms Mallon seeking an assurance that the Ballynahinch scheme remains a priority for her department and that construction work will start as soon as possible.In addition, Rowallane councillor Billy Walker is tabling a notice of motion at the February meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council seeking across-the-board political support to seek an urgent meeting with Ms Mallon discuss the next step in the construction of the bypass.He also confirmed that Strangford MP, Jim Shannon, has written to Ms Mallon on the issue and is seeking a meeting with her to discuss the issue.There has been major progress on work on the near two-mile scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads, with work already completed on a major archaeological investigation along parts of the route.Work was due to complete on the schemersquos economic appraisal before the end of last year, with roads engineers confirming recently that in order to advance the bypass schemersquos state of readiness, preparatory work on contract documents was ongoing to ldquominimise the time required to initiate a procurement competition, should funding become available for construction.The by-pass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district, is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with roads officials insisting that it will greatly benefit both strategic and local road users by reducing journey times and improving road safety.They are also confident that the schemersquos economic assessment demonstrates the by-pass would provide a good economic .The scheme is designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.It is also proposed that a section of the bypass will pass under part of the Crossgar Road with a  metre long bridge constructed to take traffic over Ballynahinch River.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.Mr Hazzard said that following his decision to formally sign off the scheme at the end of , the government department had been working through ious legal stages to ensure the scheme could commence as soon as possible.ldquoA programme of geotechnical investigation works on lands along theof the scheme was completed in  with advanced archeological investigation works completed last year, he confirmed.ldquoThis allowed the Department to move ahead with the final stage of preparing contract documentation in readiness of funding becoming available to construct the scheme.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWith an Infrastructure Minister now in place following the restoration of Stormont this week, funding should now be signed off and construction allowed to commence as soon as possible.Cllr Walker said it was the view of many, including senior roads engineers, that the multi-million pound scheme was vital to the survival of Ballynahinch town centre and will play a signicant role in helping boost the wider South Down economy.He said given that the project is shovel ready, it is essential that the cash is earmarked to allow construction work to start this year is forthcoming.ldquoMoving forward what is now required is the finance to build this scheme, continued Cllr Walker.ldquoIt is clear to me that when you look at other parts of Northern Ireland that Down District has consistently missed out on major roads funding. That must change and the cash needed to build Ballynahinchrsquos new bypass must be made available.The Rowallane councillor said that the bypass can help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre and act as a catalyst to encourage new investment.Cllr Walker added: ldquoThe eagerly-awaited scheme can address town centre gridlock and along the main approach roads. Ballynahinch is used as a gateway by visitors to Newcastle and the wider Mournes area in particular and we need to see work on the by-pass starting as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Charity ride helps African water plan
story: A PROJECT to provide African schoolchildren with clean drinking water is pound, better off thanks to the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride.Joan Cunningham, organiser of the annual festive event, recently presented a cheque to Pius Kulama, who works for I am Family Ministries in Uganda.Piusrsquos passion and dream is to help change the lives of everyone in the village and community where he was brought up.He explained the first thing needed was clean fresh water, for which a bore hole is vital. The bore hole will cost pound, and the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride is committed to raising the necessary funds.Pius was a special guest at last monthrsquos charity ride and left a great impression on everyone he came into contact with.Pius lost both his parents to Aids when he was four years old and his little sister was just two.They were both looked after by the community in his village until he took very ill. Thanks to Rock Ministries, he was taken to the Ugandan capital, Kampala, where an operation saved his le.Aged , he was brought to Saintfield by Rock Ministries NI in  as a member of the Mawamba Choir, who delighted everyone in Saintfield with their singing and dancing and rode in the late George Fawcettrsquos carriages.With the help and sponsorship from I Am Family Ministries, Pius went on to university and achieved a Bachelor of Science degree in Quantitative Economics.Pius now works for I Am Family Ministries in Uganda and is also principal of a school for  orphaned and needy children in home village.A coffee morning to raise further funds for the bore hole appeal is being organised by Barbara Ennis, from Bright, in The Civic Centre, Downshire Estate, Downpatrick, on Thursday, February , from .am until  noon. Everyone is welcome.The  Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride will take place on Saturday, December ..prettyPhoto

title: Connaire chases Noel to finish line
story: THE fth race in the BornRun Forest series took place in Tollymore Forest Park on Saturday and almost  runners showed up to the event which offered both a k and a k route.Running conditions were perfect on the day and Tollymore provided the perfect location for this annual event which is now well-established as one of the must-do January races.Noel McNally, of Road Runners, was the first across the line in the k race, followed by Connaire McVeigh, of Newcastle AC and Brendan McIlhannon in third.The first female finisher in the k was Amy Bulman, of Willowfield Harriers. Karen Wilton, of Jog Lisburn, was runner-up and Chloe Gillard, of Fitness Factory, finished third.The K was won by junior runner Tom Crudgington, of Newcastle AC. David Conlfe, of PACE Running finished second and his clubmate Ricky McKnight came third.Junior athlete Lauren Madine, of East Down AC, came first in the female k race with her clubmate Anna Gardiner following two seconds behind to take the runner-up position. Dromorersquos Lily Rimmer came third.The next race in the award winning series takes place in Gosford Forest Parkon January . For more information or to enter go to www.bornrunevents.prettyPhoto

title: Delay to £3m Lidl proposal
story: A RECOMMENDATION to approve a new poundm Lidl store in Newcastle has been deferred by Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.The decision to defer the plannersrsquo recommendation was taken at last weekrsquos committee meeting in Newry after a late submission was received.The supermarket giant is seeking permission for the new store at the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site.The development proposal also includes a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team at the . acre Shanslieve Drive site in the resort, with entry to the proposed store via Bryansford Road.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site were originally submitted in January  with permission being sought to bulldoze the existing school to pave the way for the construction of a new food store and the dedicated centre for the volunteers who run the mountain rescue team. Lidl, which currently employs  staff, claims its proposal will create  new jobs.In late November, the local council confirmed that outline permission granted in March for the multi-million pound development was to be quashed as a result of a judicial review brought by developer Don Holdings Ltd.However, days later, the agenda for the December meeting of the Planning Committee included a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve the new store proposal. The recommendation was subsequently withdrawn, but features on the agenda for todayrsquos meeting with a recommendation to approve.The Newcastle development proposal includes plans for almost  parking spaces, eight of which are reserved for mountain rescue team members.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal, with planners receiving  objections. Five five letters in support of the new rescue team base proposal have also been lodged.Lidl has consistently argued that its current base at Railway Street in Newcastle is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.It says the Railway Street base was only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found.Lidl says it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the Shanslieve Drive site became available, with the planned mountain rescue team centre providing the volunteers with a permanent base.Objectors to the new store proposal claim that there are ldquoserious errors in the transport assessment submitted in conjunction with the planning application, inaccurate land ownership information, unachievable visibility spays and out-of-season traffic surveys.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokeswoman confirmed yesterday that the Lidl planning application was deferred to allow further consideration of a number of submissions received by the local authority.She added: ldquoThe Council is endeavouring to bring this application back to the Planning Committee in Februarypossible..prettyPhoto

title: Experienced Crossgar lift Mahon Cup in style
story: WITH multiple champions on show, including Crossgarrsquos recently-crowned All-Ireland winner, Kenny Campbell, the Mahon Billiards Cup final just before Christmas promised much and didnrsquot disappoint. First up was Christian Kirk from St Patrsquos against John Weston. Kirk started well with breaks of ,  and  to take an early -point lead.Weston gradually found his range and four  plus breaks of his own saw him take the lead at  points to Kirkrsquos .However, currently double Downpatrick inidual champion, Kirk responded superbly to hit a lovely  break, overtaking Weston before eventually winning out at  points to Westonrsquos battling .On the other table, Frankie Trainor was up against Colin Flanagan and was finding points hard to come by as Flanagan hit the ground running.A string of smallish breaks and a well-constructed , saw Flanagan race ahead, leading - and - as he eyed the winning line.Trainor, though, wasnrsquot finished and breaks of  followed by a gutsy  at the death, brought an air of respectability to the result as Flanagan won out at  points to .But for the late breaks by Kirk and Trainor, the match might have been over bar the shouting.As it was, after handicap adjustment, Crossgar were to take just a two point lead into the final tie between former Northern Ireland champion John McIntyre and Campbell.The Crossgar contingent were buoyed when Campbellrsquos first scoring visit to the table saw him make a  break.However, McIntrye wasnrsquot put off and breaks of  and  saw him lead by  on the board and  in the match overall.Campbell bagged another  break to re-take the lead, which was to change no less than seven times in the match.After a thrilling finale, further late breaks of  and  saw the younger Campbell break clear at the crucial time, as he closed out the match at  points to McIntyrersquos .League billiards correspondent Robert Pollock did the presentation honours, handing the Mahon Cup to Crossgar captain Weston.John thanked Drumaness for hosting the final in immaculate playing conditions, as usual and commiserated with the losing St Patrsquos boys before everyone enjoyed the usual post-match refreshments.Many thanks go to Seamus, Gary and Marty for their renowned hospitality.ST PATRICKrsquoS B CROSSGAR .prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 8%2C 1980
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash A plan to spruce-up Ballynahinch Square has been agreed between the Department of the Environment and the owners.It is expected to cost somewhere in the region of pound,, which will be shared equally between the Department and the Ker Estate, with Down Council acting as agents. It was confirmed this week that an offer of grant aid had been made by the Department and had been agreed in principle.The work will be done under an Environmental Improvement Spruce-Up Scheme and is aimed at giving the area a badly-needed facelt. Department officials are insisting that work begins before March , otherwise they will withdraw grant aid.ldquoTherersquos a limit to the money and itrsquos not an elaborate scheme, but wersquore hoping it will leave the centre of Ballynahinch in a more acceptable manner, a spokesman for the Department said.The whole square will be resurfaced and drained and a low wall is to be built all around, with vehicle and pedestrian access points.To coincide with the facelt, Department officials, in conjunction with the townrsquos Chamber of Trade, are appealing to owners of property in the square to carry out facelts to their own buildings.ldquoTherersquos not much point in brightening up the squarepeople do not take a civic pride, but perhapswe start the work others will he more amenable to doing something, the spokesman added.DOWNPATRICK mdash A pound, contract has been finalised this week for the building of new squash courts, with changing and recreational facilities, in Downpatrick.The new complex is an extension to existing facilities at the De La Salle schoolsrsquo campus where the sports club already enjoys the use of facilities for badminton and other indoor sports.Work is due to commence later this month by local firm Messrs Hugh J OrsquoBoyle Ltd, who have been awarded the contract, and it is hoped to have the project fully operational before Christmas this year.Announcing the details at a regular meeting of the La Salle Union Past Pupils Association, the president, Mr Michael Hamill, thanked the De La Salle community and the Department of Education for their financial support.He stated that the complex would be available to all members or the local community and hoped that this would encourage many past pupils of all the De La Salle schools to renew their association with the past pupilsrsquo union.BINS mdash Down Council clerk Mr Seamus Byrne has publicly apologised for the ldquomost inefficient bin collection service in the district during the past fortnight.Mr Byrne admitted this week that most areas in Down District are two days behind schedule, but he promised that every attempt was being made to bring the service up to date.He explained to a meeting of councillors that there had been number of problems with men of sick and with breakdowns in the councilrsquos fleet of lorries.One of the biggest problems, said Mr Byrne, was finding drivers for the lorries because a number of men had refused to do overtime. ldquoThe men are not obliged to do overtime and we cannot force them, he explained.Mr Byrne said all vehicles were on the road last weekend with the exception of one lorry in Downpatrick and he promised that all lorries would be in operation throughout this week.When quizzed by several councillors on a collection rota to clear the backlog, Mr Byrne stressed it would be nearly impossible to say what was going to happen in each area.ldquoI apologise for the most inefficient service, but every attempt is being made to put it in order, he added.FARMING mdash The total agricultural labour force in Co Down stands at , mdash the second highest in the province. The figure is contained in the agricultural census on the province, compiled by the Department of Agriculture and published this week.The total labour force is just  short of the labour force in Tyrone, the largest in the province. A breakdown of the total figure shows that the total workforce, excluding owners and their wives, is , in Co Down.The census also reveals there are , owners, partners and directors on Co Down farms and a breakdown of this figure shows that farming locally is still very much male dominated.Co Down farmers have traditionally required more seasonal or casual workers than where, with , being taken on in . Other figures contained in the report include , full-time family workers,  part-time family workers,  full-time hired workers and  part-time hired workers in Co Down.NEWCASTLE mdash The death has taken place in Cranborne, Victoria, Australia, of Father George Todd, formerly of Newcastle.Father Todd was ordained in All Hallows College, Dublin, in  and celebrated his first Mass in St Maryrsquos Church, Newcastle, on June  of that year.While he was awaiting his call to Australia he was appointed assistant curate in Castlewellan where the late Dean C McKenna was the PP.In  Fr Todd went to Australia and  years later he ed home on his first visit. He is survived by a sister and brother, who also reside in Australia.KILLINCHY mdash Former Killinchy man Norman McMordie has won the Young Farmersrsquo Clubs farm management competition.Norman, who received a travel bursary from the Northern Bank as his prize, is no stranger to success in farming circles. Last year he won two top awards and finished third in another major competition.Now , Norman will be able to put his skills to good use on his fatherrsquos farm at Ballygowan. His father is a well known breeder of pedigree polled Hereford and Simmental bulls and Norman helps out on the farm at weekends and on holidays.He moved to the Banbridge area due to work commitments as a sales development representative with Richardsonrsquos Fertilisers. Before that he was a member of Killinchy YFC.COMBER mdash A  year-old Comber girl, Libby Smyth, who is playing Fairy Lethargia in the current production of Mother Goose at the Arts Theatre in Befast, is really pulling in the pantomime fans.During rehearsals someone suggested Libby should try impersonating the Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher. She did and it has now become one for the most popular features of the show. Libbyrsquos updated and light-hearted Thatcherisms have the audience rolling in their seats.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh was the venue last night for a big training night for Scout leaders. The event in the Shore Street youth hall is one of a number organised for Scout leaders in Co Down this month.The training programme is being co-ordinated by Scout headquarters, with the new county commissioner, Mr Clive Scoular, doing much of the groundwork.Last night was the turn of the Beaver leaders, with the district commissioner, Mr Harry Galbraith, from Downpatrick, and the assistant county commissioner , Teresa Savage, introducing the activities.SAINTFIELD mdash Mr David Napier, of Belfast Road, Saintfield, has won pound in a competition organised by Dromona Butter. David, a schoolteacher at Bangor Grammar School, answered six questions relating to butter and supplied a slogan. He was presented with a pound cheque for his efforts.DRUMANESS mdash A flock of sheep were attacked by dogs at Crawfordstown Road, Drumaness, last Thursday in the latest sheep worrying outbreak to hit the area. Six sheep were worried, but fortunately only one was seriously injured.KILKEEL mdash A Kilkeel man who has been honorary secretary of the townrsquos branch of the Royal National Leboat Institution for  years is to be rewarded with a gold badge for devoted service.Mr Cecil Baxter is to receive the badge, there highest the RNLI can offer, at the annual presentation of RNLI awards in the Royal Festival Hall, London, in May..prettyPhoto

title: in sessions to discuss town centre development plans
story: RATEPAYERS are being asked to help shape a special study being undertaken by Newry, Mourne and Down Council on the districtrsquos retail and commercial leisure needs over the next decade.The study will examine the need for additional floorspace and consider how the local authorityrsquos future planning polices for retail and commercial use could assist in sustaining the vitality and viability of town centres.The information contained in the new study will be used to help formulate the districtrsquos new local development plan.A series of so-called -in sessions are being held this week in Ballynahinch, Saintfield, Newcastle and Downpatrick to provide people with an opportunity to review initial findings by consultants and to provide comment ahead of the formal publication of the study.Downpatrick area councillor, Dermot Curran, said it is essential that the local authority does all it can to grow the districtrsquos economy.He said that moving forward, the focus must be on job creation and helping deliver economic regeneration to benefit existing traders and businesses keen on investing in the area.Cllr Curran said it was important that the council works on building key relationships with the business community, from small independent traders upwards to see what assistance they can be provided with to ensure they remain at the heart of the districtrsquos economy.He said he was keen to see the detail of the retail and commercial leisure need study, in particular, the levels of expenditure in the districtrsquos towns and villages.He also said it was important that the local authority supports and works alongside businesses which provide employment.ldquoIt is important to be at the forefront of supporting the districtrsquos business community, he continued. ldquoThere is not point waiting for new economic opportunities to arise. We must go out there and grab them by selling what the district has to offer.Cllr Curran said given that the Newry, Mourne and Down area is the third largest of the provincersquos  district councils, it should be an ldquoattractive proposition for potential investors.ldquoThe focus moving forward must be on new job creation in both the public and private sector. It is important that we sell what the area has to offer.In relation to public sector job opportunities, Cllr Curran said available space at the Downshire Civic Centre could be utilised by a number of government departments keen to decentralise their operations from the greater Belfast area.He continued: ldquoNew investment will not happen out of the blue. We all have a duty to work together to secure it. I believe we need new hotels and there is a need for such a facility in the Downpatrick area and hope see progress on this issue in the near future.Cllr Curran is particularly keen to see the proposed commercial development at the site of the former Irish Street police station in Downpatrick and a number of adjacent derelict buildings progressed this year.ldquoThis exciting proposal has the potential to restore Downpatrickrsquos economic heart, create jobs and, most importantly, provide a boost for existing businesses via increased footfall, he said.Cllr Curran also warned that while attracting new investment is crucial, cracking Downpatrickrsquos traffic congestion problem is also essential.ldquoGridlock continues to stle town centre investment and we need to act quickly. While expensive schemes have been proposed in the past, nothing has happened. We must see progress in  and ensure roads officials deliver.ldquoWork was completed recently on a major upgrade of the Collinsrsquo Corner junction and while welcome, I and others remain to be convinced that it will address congestion problems in the heart of the town.Cllr Curran said roads officials also deserve praise for the improvement scheme in Fountain Street and hopes that in  efforts will be made by the Department for Infrastructure to improve Edward Street.He added: ldquoThis is a real problem area which has not been addressed. The presence of a busy primary school should ensure that roads officials redouble their efforts to improve driver and pedestrian safety. In addition, urgent action is needed to ban large vehicles, especially lorries, from this built-up area..prettyPhoto

title: Inspirational Seaforde woman to take on seventh marathon
story: A SEAFORDE woman is getting ready to run her seventh marathon after recovering from cancer.Pat Shields is an inspiration to those of us who have already broken our New Year resolutions.In her darkest moments of , while she was undergoing a series of chemotherapy treatments to fight a cancer diagnosis, Pat recalls feeling at a low ebb.ldquoIt was bleak but I found something deep within me to keep going, she said. ldquoPeople who undergo treatment for cancer need to know there is light at the end of that very dark tunnel. They need to keep fighting because everything you think you have lost will all come back again.ldquoIt can be a time when you donrsquot look great, your confidence is low and even your memory begins to fade. People must realise it is not the end of the world.Before she discovered a cyst on her breast, Pat had already completed four marathons having recaptured the joy of running she knew as a young girl growing up around the fields of Ballynagross, outside Downpatrick.Pat said: ldquoI used to take off and run for miles, setting my own routes across the fields and making the most of the fresh air, but I put it all aside when my children came along.It was only when she reached her late s that the opportunity arose for her to take up running again.She said: ldquoMurlough Athletics Club in Dundrum were holding a recruitment drive at the time. The club was offering a six-week programme for beginners, three times a week.Pat soon rediscovered the running bug that had lay dormant for years. She said: ldquoWe gradually built up three miles at a time. When I joined Murlough AC, it had around  members and it has grown to become one of the biggest clubs in Northern Ireland, with  members.Pat describes her fellow runners as ldquolovely honest people, who are always there for her. She said: ldquoThey have certainly helped tremendously with my recovery. They are non-judgemental and share a great deal of their own lives with you. Wersquore like a family in away.Pat believes it was having a reasonable level of fitness that helped her to recover from the devastating diagnosis. She said: ldquoI was at my fittest. I was running marathons. I just couldnrsquot take it in.ldquoIt was crushing news, she said. ldquoUp until that point I felt younger and fitter than I had in ages. The word cancer certainly stops you in your tracks.In spite of the darkness, Pat felt encouraged to get well and dreamed of crossing another finish line.Pat is currently training for her seventh marathon run which is taking place in Paris this April.Running has taken Pat to many cities in the world, including London and Dublin, but she says nothing compares to the beauty and charm of running the Mourne Way ndashthe off road run that traverses the foothills of the Mourne Mountains from Newcastle to Rostrevor.Pat says that before her illness she would give up too easily. Now she gives up on nothing.ldquoRunning is part of my le now, she remarked. ldquoOne of the many upsides is I never have to watch what I eat. No one can say they are never too old to run. I refer to my setback as just a blip in a chapter of my le.She adds: ldquoI would encourage people just to get back up and rediscover the good things in le. Do rest, but never believe that itrsquos over.ldquoMaybe one day trouble may knock on my door again but when it does Irsquoll just have to get up and get on with it again..prettyPhoto

title: Lauren takes major 5k title
story: AT the fth race in the BornRun series at Tollymore Forest Park over the weekend the sun shone and the mood was good.The k race left the car park area and headed down towards the main Tollymore entrance then turned up to the right taking the runners down gravel forest trails for most of the first k.As to be expected in a forest park, there were then a few uphills followed by flatter parts and then one more incline coming up to the last k. After that it was straight towards the finish line on good ground allowing for fast finishes.Lauren Madine maintained her winning streak in this series, with a spirited run, holding on to first place in . with Anna Gardiner, second female, a mere second behind.Lily Rimmer, of Dromore, completed the ladiesrsquo podium in ..Sharon Madine demonstrated that she hasnrsquot been slacking over the holiday either, coming fourth female in a respectable .. Another good day out for the EDAC trio.The rest of the club must have been in recovery mdash either from the exploits of the Cracker the week before or simply the aftermath of the festivities as no one  turned out to race over the weekend.There were, however, a few notable performances in parkruns with Mackenzie Murray claiming the title of first finishing male in Castlewellan for the first time.He finished in  minutes dead, slightly disappointed not to break that barrier, but the sub  is surely in the offing.Oliver Robinson got the year off to a good start by breaching the  minute barrier on New Yearrsquos Day and then further whittling his time to . on Saturday past, so plenty for him to aim for. Suzy Smith has also managed to PB on her first two runs at Castlewellan in January. At Victoria Park on Saturday Aaron McGrady was the first finisher in ..Loose endsOn New Yearrsquos Day Paddy McDonald was the sole representative in the annual Race Across the Glens, in Glenarf Forest Park, which used to be on my lsquonot to be missed listrsquo and he did well to complete the gruelling route in under the hour, clocking .. Well done Paddy.Also taking advantage of her Christmas visit to the locality was Hannah Somani, who was here to participate in the Cracker race, as she finally took possession of her Podium  Sport voucher prize, resulting from her efforts in the Seeley Cup race at the end of November, in which she was the third scoring member of the East Down AC female team which took second place overall.Coming upThe calendar for the next few weeks offers plenty of cross country for juniors and seniors alike.This weekend is the Mathieson Cup and Shield at Mallusk on Sunday with entries on the day. Details can be found at https:athleticsni.org Fixtures Mathieson-Cup-and-Shield- while on Sunday, January , round four of this yearrsquos McGradyrsquos Financial Services Junior Cross Country takes place in Delamont Country Park beginning at pm.Jimmyrsquos TenItrsquos hard to believe that wersquore talking about Jimmyrsquos Ten again, how time flies. Bt the online entry facility is already open at www.athleticsni.org and entries are flooding in.This is your opportunity to take advantage of the attractive early bird entry rates which will be applicable until January . Not only that, but it will ensure your entry for what is regarded as one of the top k road races in the calendar.k early bird until January , costs poundpoundmdash thereafter pound  until close on Friday, March , or the cap of  is reached.k relayearly bird until January , pound, thereafter pound until close on Friday March, , or the cap of  teams is reached.So, donrsquot say you havenrsquot been warned. Best wishes to all local runners for the coming season and indeed throughout the year..prettyPhoto

title: Magpies in final flight
story: MAGNIFICENT Cill Chua are through to the All-Ireland Club SFC final for the first time.The Magpies overcame red hot favourites St Endarsquos Ballyboden - to - at Kingspan Breffni on Saturday and they will now face defending champions Corofin at Croke Park on Sunday, January .Goals from Ryan Johnston and Daryl Branagan proved crucial in cancelling out an eight-point haul from Ballybodenrsquos Basquel brothers in a thrilling encounter that went to the wire.Cill Chua manager Mickey Moran changed things around for this clash and yet again his tactics proved spot-on as the Dublin kingpins were unable to break free from their shackles.The amazing odyssey for the East Down side continues all the way to the biggest day in the club calendar against perhaps the greatest side in the history of club football mdash a fact that is not lost on team selector Conleth Gilligan.ldquoTherersquos a great buzz around Cill Chua at the moment and in the wider Down area in general, he said after Saturdayrsquos match.ldquoDown football has been a wee bit stagnant this last while. That will give everybody a lt going into the New Year.Gilligan described Corofin as an ldquoncredible team.He went on: ldquoFor a club team to go with that level of consistency, we know the challenge thatrsquos there. From that perspective, wersquore there.ldquoWersquore going to savour this good feeling and wersquoll be back down to earth tomorrow with a bang knowing wersquore playing one of the best club teams that probably ever played the game.Cill Chua have certainly flourished with the underdogrsquos mantle, but Gilligan is not unduly worried by that tag.ldquoIt is not something we pay much attention to, he revealed. ldquoWe went to a lot of games ndash even the county final in Down mdash with people tipping against us, so it isnrsquot unusual. Itrsquos not something thatrsquos ever talked about, but players are players and they want to put two fingers up to the critics and Kilcoo are no dferent, he admitted.Gilligand, who is manager Moranrsquos right hand man, is confident his side will acquit themselves well at Croke Park against Corofin.ldquoA team that is going for three All-Irelands, itrsquos phenomenal and wersquoll just have to prepare as best we can and give the best account of ourselves, he said.ldquoGetting to Croke Park is the pinnacle for every player. Some of these boys have been soldiering for - years.ldquoThis is just reward for a lot of hard graft. Itrsquos where we want to be and now our whole focus will be on trying to become the All-Ireland club champions.ldquoObviously, itrsquos a great thrill to be looking forward to playing at Croke Park. It will be a very special occasion for the club, but itrsquos a massive test at the same time.ldquoThis club has shown tremendous determination over a number of years and now they will bid to do themselves justice on the biggest stage..prettyPhoto

title: Minister vows to end strikes with pay deal
story: HEALTH staff across the district were yesterday digesting the news that new Stormont Health Minister Robin Swann had confirmed that pay parity with their colleagues in England can now be restored.He told the Assembly that it would cost an extra poundm that would come from within existing Stormont finances.Mr Swann met with representatives from a number of leading health trade unions to brief them on the decision, describing the talks as ldquoconstructive.The new man in charge of the Provincersquos health portfolio said the ldquobreakthrough that we all wanted has been achieved this isa good day after some very dficult days.Mr Swann announced that the Department of Health had already gathered together poundm to increase pay for health workers, with an extra poundm being pulled from existing finances at Stormont.His decision to address the pay issue came after a series of strikes involving staff across the health and social services sector over pay and staffing levels.Nurses and other health workers in Northern Ireland have been taking industrial action over pay and staffing levels, with Mr Swann confirming that his officials would work with the unions on the issue of safe staffing levels in the health service and hopes a plan can be drawn up to establish such levels ldquowithin a reasonable period of time.Today, representatives from trade unions representing nurses and all health and social services staff will meet with Department of Health officials, with Mr Swann hoping for a ldquoswt end to their industrial action.He added: ldquoOur nurses and great social care workers can come off the picket-line.Prior to yesterdayrsquos announcement, local nurses said that they hoped that theof Stormont would pave the way for the pay parity and staffing issues to be finally addressed.Ahead of yesterdayrsquos meeting, the RCN said while welcoming the restoration of the Stormont administration, nurses had been made many promises.The RCNrsquos Northern Ireland Director, Pat Cullen, said nurses wanted to see those promises converted into action.Last Wednesday and Friday, nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals took part in the latest round of stoppages and were buoyed by the support of passing motorists and others as they manned the picket-line at the entrance to the Downshire Civic Centre.Braving bitterly cold conditions last Friday morning, nurses were hoping for positive news from Stormont, hours after Secretary of State Julian Smith and Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney had published the New Decade New Approach document.Nurses, who had sacriced another dayrsquos pay, were joined at one stage on the picket-line by South Eastern Trust interim chief executive Seamus McGoran and Roisin Coulter, the organisationrsquos director of planning.Nurses said that they hoped that the political parties would go back into government and that their demands for pay parity and safe staffing levels would be met.ldquoWe believe that the collective pressure of health service staff has ensured that politicians know that they must get back to Stormont, said nurse Irene Murray.ldquoWe do not want to be used as political pawns and hope that there is cross-party agreement for politicians to get back to work. While pay parity and safe services are key issues for us, the key thing is that there are enough recurrent resources in place to deliver this now and in the future.Irene said the RCN is about putting patients first, describing the scale of the hospital waiting list issue as ldquounacceptable.She added: ldquoEmploying more nurses can help bring waiting lists down. This is not a new phenomena. It is tough to work as a nurse and it is not an easy job. But we currently have a situation where some nurses are taking on extra shts to earn more money, but that is just an unacceptable way to live.Alison Megarry said patients are nursesrsquo primary concern and at the heart of what they do, highlighting the need to keep staff working in Northern Ireland to ensure they donrsquot go across the water and donrsquot come back.She revealed that she was talking to a nursing sister last week who was working on international recruitment for nurses in Mumbai to work in Northern Ireland.ldquoThe nurses in India said why would they come here when the pay is less than it is in England, Scotland and Wales. I believe thatwe can keep our nurses here, it will help to tackle the waiting list issue, she said. ldquoThe big issue we have is that the population is ageing and people are living longer which therefore impacts on waiting lists.Nurse Sonia McCoubrey said that while pay parity is one issue, additional nurses are also required. She said many newly qualied nurses are choosing to go to England, Scotland or Wales because the money is better.She also said she worries about the safety of newly qualied nurses managing dficult situations and the patients they are caring for.ldquoYou have trolley waits and people lying in corridors. There is no privacy, no dignity and the situation is appalling. You go home at night after a sht burnt out and worried about what you have seen, the nurse added.Nurse Donna Boyd also expressed concern about waiting lists and said she fears that the situation is going to get worse, forcing many people to go private.ldquoIf more money is put into the system nurses are quite happy to do even more to help reduce waiting lists. All nurses go and above what is required of them when they are working, often staying after their scheduled quitting time which is unpaid work, she said.ldquoWith more people going private because of y waiting lists, a lot of the doctors and consultants are taking on private lists which then impacts on the NHS list. I have friends who were nurses who have left the profession to work in supermarkets because they have burnt themselves out. They canrsquot cope with the demands being made on them, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Now is the time for delivery – McGrath
story: THE restoration of the Assembly and Northern Ireland Executive should herald delivery for people at the start of a new decade, according to South Down SDLP MLA Colin McGrath.Mr McGrath was able to take his seat in the Assembly chamber for the first time in three years last Saturday, an occasion which he described as a ldquomomentous day for Northern Ireland and its future.He said that with so many issues staring people in the face including Brexit, y hospital waiting times, workersrsquo rights and wages, welfare issues and an education system in crisis, Northern Ireland needed a restored and fully ing Assembly and Executive to deal with these mammoth issues.The Assemblyman described his partyrsquos decision to re-enter the Executive as an act of ldquotrust and goodwill.He continued: ldquoWe all know the reasons why the last Executive failed and these have been well covered. While elements of this need to be addressed, which we wait for patiently, the SDLP team is firmly rooted in looking forward to a brighter future for all our people.ldquoWe now have our new Minister for Infrastructure in place in our deputy leader Nichola Mallon. Like all constituencies, South Down will benefit greatly from having as hard a working, fresh thinking and energetic a Minister in place as Nichola. The Infrastructure Ministry is also essential to our shared future.Mr McGrath said the SDLP had always been committed to ldquouniting peoplersquos hearts and minds first, suggesting that in Ms Mallon, his party had a minister in place who was ldquorooted in this and will now unite and connect the physical landscape of the north and the wider island of Ireland.The MLA declared: ldquoThese are exciting times and I look forward to meeting all of our new ministers and addressing the needs of the people in South Down, such as the protection of local and rural healthcare centres and rural schools etc. While these times are exciting, they are also faced with very serious pragmatism.ldquoPeople have been crying out for MLAs to get back to work as fully as possible. The SDLP has been fighting for this for three years and we can finally do it. Now, however, as we enter this new decade, is the time for delivery..prettyPhoto

title: O’Toole MLA in South Belfast
story: A FORMER Downpatrick man has been selected as the SDLPrsquos Assembly member for South Belfast.Matthew OrsquoToole mdash who was educated at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and is a former Downing Street and Treasury adviser mdash replaces Claire Hanna following her election to Westminster last month.Mr OrsquoToole, who is the nephew of former Foyle MP and SDLP leader Mark Durkan, has a background in economic policy and communications.He says he is delighted to be asked to serve the people of South Belfast at what he described as ldquothis critical moment.ldquoThe absence of power-sharing has put immense pressure on public services, especially the health service, which is felt acutely in places like South Belfast, he said.Mr OrsquoToole, who left the British government in September  and works for communications consultancy Powerscourt, as well as contributing regular journalism on UK and Irish politics, said Brexit had made Northern Ireland ldquoimmensely vulnerable andwas damaging to community relations.He said the election to Westminster of ldquoprogressive, Remain voices like Ms Hanna and SDLP leader Colum Eastwood was good news and pledged to defend Northern Ireland from the effects of Brexit.ldquoI am humbled to be asked to serve a constituency that is Northern Irelandrsquos most erse and open, continued Mr OrsquoToole.ldquoI believe deeply in building in a shared society and South Belfast is an example of how a erse community can live and work together, I am proud to be their representative.Mr Eastwood said he was delighted that the party has announced that someone of Matthewrsquos calibre is stepping forward to join the SDLP Assembly team and represent the people of South Belfast.ldquoWith a strong background in economic policy, having worked across government and the private sector, Matthew brings an immense amount of experience that will be critical to our efforts to rebalance Northern Irelandrsquos economy, attract new jobs and defend people here from the impact of Brexit, said the SDLP leader.He added: ldquoI look forward to working with him at a critical time for politics in the north.Ms Hanna said her successor will make an ldquooutstanding Assembly member..prettyPhoto

title: Roads closed after gales uproot trees
story: STORM Brendan unleashed his fury across the district on Monday.Fallen trees forced the closure of roads mdash several of which still remained impassable or partially closed yesterday morning mdash while a small number of homes were left without electricity in the wake of the raging storm.Coastal roads in Newcastle, Strangford and Portaferry were buffeted with high waves, making driving hazardous for motorists, as storm gales reached speeds of up to mph.The Met Office had issued a yellow storm warning to hit Co Down. However, the district felt the brunt of the storm from early morning to late afternoon, making the daily commute to and from work and school dficult for many travellers.Early on Monday, Newry, Mourne and Down Council closed Delamont Country Park in Killyleagh ldquoas a precautionary measure along with several other of its parks in South Down. Castlewellan mountain bike trail was also closed.The Strangford to Portaferry ferry service was temporarily halted due to the gales. The landing area and the approach road to the ferry in Strangford was at one point swamped with water several feet deep.Police closed South Promenade in Newcastle in both directions due to the adverse weather conditions and advised motorists to seek alternative routes.There were also unconfirmed local reports that a boat sank in Newcastle harbour due to the ferocity of the winds and waves.The Killough Road in Downpatrick was closed until late yesterday afternoon.Also in Downpatrick, the Killyleagh Road was closed at the junction with the Strangford Road. One lane was reopened later.The fallen tree also impacted on NIE power lines, causing a loss of supply. The road was not completely open for travel until yesterday.The Old Belfast Road in Downpatrick was closed in both directions after a tree fell on the road between Quoile Bridge and the war memorial.There were also reports of road closures at Ballyknockan Road, Saintfield Ballagh Road, Newcastle and Manse Road, Carryduff Rubane Road Kircubbin and Moneyreagh Road, Ballygowan.An electricity cable came down on the Moneyscalp Road, Bryansford.Trees or branches which fell on to roads and caused issues for motorists were reported at the Buckrsquos Head, Annadoran Road area outside Downpatrick Church Road, Kilmore Saul Brae and Sievegrange Road, Downpatrick and Drumgavlin Road, near Ballynahinch.There were also reports of electricity supply being cut off in parts of the Castlewellan area..prettyPhoto

title: Streets left in darkness
story: WHILE the lights are back on at Stormont they are continuing to go out across the district at an alarming rate mdash and with little prospect of them being repaired any time soon.The Down Recorder can reveal this week that almost  street lights are currently not working in East Down, plunging many areas into darkness and the Department for Infrastructure confirming that due to budgetary pressures, it is only able to provide a limited repair service.Province-wide, , street lights are currently not working with the government department having only eight engineers at its disposal to repair all of them.Downpatrick tops the league table for broken street lights in East Down with  in need of repair, with Newcastle sitting in second place. Across the resort,  street lights are not working.The figures are available on the NI Direct website under the reporting fault problems menu with other districthot-spots including Ballynahinch where  street lights are currently out of order.Elsewhere,  faults have been reported in Killyleagh, with  brought to the government departmentrsquos attention in Castlewellan and Crossgar. In Saintfield,  faults have been reported.In Ballygowan,  street lights are currently out of order with  and  faults reported in Ardglass and Killough respectively.Sixteen street lights are out of order in Dundrum with  faults reported in Drumaness. The figures for the Spa and Clough are  and nine respectively.Last month, the Department for Infrastructure confirmed that its current budget for street lighting repairs was approximately poundm, explaining that the figure was much lower than the pound.m needed to provide a full street lighting repair service.It also revealed that repairs are now generally limited to those that can be carried out by the departmentrsquos internal street lighting workforce which only consists of five full and three part time electricians.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran described the number of reported street light faults across large parts of East Down as ldquoalarming and hopes that the money to expedite much-needed repairs will be earmarked by the new Stormont Executive.He said broken street lights in many areas represent a health and safety issue, explaining that an examination of every town and village across the district will reveal a signicant number of faults.Cllr Curran described faulty street lights as a ldquohot topic with politicians being contacted about the issue on all almost daily basis. He said the legacy of underfunding the roads department has experienced is now clear for all to see.The politician said many will be concerned that the Department for Infrastructure does not have the money it requires to carry out much-needed repairs.ldquoWhile I understand the decision to prioritise emergency repairs, there is no doubt that the alarming figure of almost  faulty street lights across East Down is simply going to increase. Clearly the issue is going to get a lot worse before it gets better, he said.ldquoStreet lights which are not working in areas where elderly people and indeed young families live poses a major problem. A fully working street lighting system provides residents with a sense of security and helps deter would-be criminals.Cllr Curran said that while the new Stormont Executive will inevitably face calls for investment in many key areas including health and education, the Department of Infrastructure also required an injection of funding.He added: ldquoWhile the focus for some will be on major new roads schemes which is understandable, it is clear that the creaking infrastructure the government department is responsible for, including street lighting, requires major cash injection.ldquoThe street lighting issues requires immediate attention. We are still in the grip of winter and several months away from the clearer evenings. Now that we have a local minister in place, I hope to meet her on this issue and other matters of local importance.A spokeswoman for the Department for Infrastructure said that in common with many other parts of the public service, the Department continued to face budget challenges and resources were currently not available to provide for a full street lighting repair service.She added: ldquoDue to this restricted service, outages are taking longer than usual to be repaired. However, priority will be given to hazardous electrical defects and group outages..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes to lawyer who was ‘a real gentleman’
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a lawyer who died last week.Mr Paul McAlinden, who was a barrister, died peacefully in Belfast City Hospital last Wednesday. He had celebrated his th birthday on Boxing Day.At Downpatrick Court last Thursday, District Judge Amanda Brady led the tributes to Mr McAlinden.She described him as ldquoa real gentleman who earnestly tried to do his best for his clients.She said Mr McAlinden was always very pleasant and that she had never heard him complain.ldquoI was always impressed by his dignity and the courage he displayed during the last several months as he battled through his illness, she remarked.ldquoJudge Brady said Mr McAlindenrsquos motivation was his family and that he was devoted to his we, Fiona, and daughter Eileen.She added: ldquoEven though we knew he was sick, the news of his passing still comes as a shock. Irsquom still in disbelief and half expecting him to walk in to the court room.Mr McAlinden worked closely with Downpatrick solicitor Joe Mullholland for many years.Mr Mulholland, who was visibly emotional, said he had lost a dear friend and colleague.Mr Mulhollandrsquos practice colleague, Mr Chris Logue, described Mr McAlinden as being ldquopart of the furniture at the firm and said he will be ldquosorely missed as his team were ldquoheavily reliant upon him.A prosecution lawyer described Mr McAlinden as an ldquoabsolute gentleman and remarked: ldquoAlthough we had many heated exchanges I never heard Paul raise his voice. He was very much a family man. We could all see how ill he was, but the news of his passing still comes as a shock.Mr McAlinden was buried on Saturday following Requiem Mass in The Good Shepherd Church, Ormeau Road, Belfast..prettyPhoto

title: Walker braves the shave for Sophie’s fundraiser
story: A LOCAL politician is having his head shaved next month to help a Ballynahinch schoolgirlrsquos fundraising initiative on behalf of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker will have his locks shaved off by  year-old Sophie Mills, who is a student at Ballynahinch High School.Sophie has been diagnosed with Albinism and is on the waiting list for a guide dog. She has previously been cane-trained by representatives from the charity and is hoping she can get a guide dog soon.Sophie is currently selling raffle tickets for a host of prizes ahead of a a key fundraising event inBallynahinch Masonic Hall on February .Sophie mdash who recently finished in the top six of a SuperValu Superstars competition ndash is keen to help the Guide Dogs charity by raising money on its behalf. She was motivated to help after discovering that it costs pound, to train a guide dog.Cllr Walker, who is no stranger to fundraising for worthy causes, is delighted he will be able to help Sophie support a charity which does not receive any government funding.ldquoI am more than happy to have my head shaved to raise money for Sophie, even though we are still in the depths of winter, he joked.ldquoI hope to raise as much as I can andanyone would like to support me they can contact me via my mobile or social media page. Sophie is on the waiting list for a guide dog and I so hope that she will get one this year.Cllr Walker, who met up with Sophie and her parents yesterday, is encouraging people to give generously and explained that he will be printing a number of sponsor sheets so people will be able to donate.ldquoI have now met Sophie several times and she is very inspirational. My fundraising target is pound and I hope that I will be able to achieve that, he added.Sophiersquos fundraising event in Ballynahinch Masonic Hall on February  featuring live music gets underway at .pm, with the entry fee pound.The winners of ious raffle prizes will be drawn on the night and Sophie hopes the evening will be a great success.Anyone wishing to support Cllr Walkerrsquos sponsored head shave can contact him on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Walsh saves Olympic dream to seal Border Cup
story: RYAN Walsh saved the best for last when Ballynahinch Olympic lted the Border Cup after a sudden death penalty shoot-out at Seaview on New Yearrsquos Day.Victory was no more than Olympic deserved after a rip-roaring and refreshingly open game ended -. The sides were still locked after extra-time and at the end of five penalties apiece when James McClean drilled Olympic - ahead.It was then left to Walsh to break the deadlock when he kept out Ruairi Fitzpatrickrsquos well-struck spot kick to seal victory before he was mobbed by his delighted team-mates.Rathfriland certainly looked the part early doors as they sprayed the ball to both flanks where Fitzpatrick and Thomas Lockhart took full advantage.Fitzpatrick, in particular, ran at Dalton Tate at every opportunity, but Rathfriland failed to take advantage of his wing trickery.The first real shot in anger came in the th minute when Olympicrsquos Anton McGrattan tested Parr, but the big custodian saved with ease.Five minutes later at the other end Dalton Tate produced a telling tackle on the edge of the six yard box to deny Fitzpatrick a certain goal.However, from the resulting corner, Stephen Hughes bundled the ball over the line when Lockhartrsquos delivery caused mayhem.Rathfriland continued to play the ball methodically through the middle where Andy Kilmartin and Hughes were dominant and with  minutes gone they teamed up with Fitzpatrick to carve out another opening for Harry Campbell, but he shot straight at Walsh.Ruairi Cunningham then created an opening for Fitzpatrick, but he was way off target as was Lockhart in the th minute. A minute later at the opposite end Jason Noade got on the end of a McGrattan corner, but headed over.It looked asRathfriland were going to take their - lead into the break as the game entered the th minute and good value they were for their lead.However, with  minutes gone Stefan Mason exploded into le. The rangy striker took on two Rathfriland defenders after picking up a long ball out of defence.He headed down the left flank and looked destined for the by-line, but stopped in his tracks, checked back, turned his markers and curled a lsquoworldyrsquo into the top corner of the net, giving Parr no chance.Two minutes later it was - Olympic and again Mason was involved. When his attempted cross was blocked, McGrattan headed the ball into Nathan Jonesrsquo path.Nothing looked on when Jones got the ball centrally, just inside the box, but he managed to get the ball from under his feet and beat Parr all ends up with a stunning finish and turn the game on its head.The second half was every bit as competitive, but Olympic seemed to have the measure of Rathfriland and were playing well within themselves until Peter Telford was given the freedom of the box and allowed to head in a Lockhart free kick to make it - in the rd minute.Jason Noade then headed a Jones free kick at lsquokeeper Parr and with  minutes played the busy McGrattan fired over after a nice build-up.Another searing run and cross from Fitzpatrick begged to be put away, but Rathfriland lacked a fox in the box and the chance was gone.Chances continued to be created at either end and with the respective lsquokeepers earning their corn with brilliant saves.However, the game was in the nd minute when Walsh came to Olympicrsquos rescue when he somehow kept out an effort from Marty Havern when the former Glenavon striker seemed certain to win the game for Rathfriland. Two periods of extra-time came and went before the dreaded penalty shoot-out took centre stage.Jones, Stevie and Jason Noade, McGrattan, Tate and James McClean netted for Olympic with Kilmartin, Johnny Roy, Nigel Prentice, Ruari Cunningham and Daryll Evans replying for Rathfriland before Walsh saved the day when he beat away Fitzpatrickrsquos penalty.Ballynahinch Olympic: Ryan Walsh, Dalton Tate, Paul Dickson, Jason Noade, Anton McGrattan, Nathan Jones, Stevie Noade, Chris McNamara, Stefan Mason, Conor Reid, Ryan Molloy. Subs: James McClean, Aaron McClean, Shane Murray.Rathfriland Rangers: Jonathan Parr, Graeme Edgar, Ruari Cunningham, Peter Telford, Ruairi Fitzpatrick, Andy Kilmartin, Harry Campbell, Stephen Hughes, Thomas Lockhart, Jonny Roy, Daryll Evans. Subs: Nigel Prentice, Marty Havern, Jonathan Scannell.Ballynahinch Olympic Rathfriland Rangers BORDER CUP FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: four people stand trial blackmail charge
story: Three men and a woman are to stand trial on charges related to the alleged blackmail of a male, who it is claimed paid out in excess of pound,.Paul Arthur Mayefrom Sallys Wood, Irvinestown is accused of demanding cash from the injured party with menaces on four occasions, the first of which was under the guise of payment to ldquorelease a lorry held at docks.He is also accused along with Patrick Thomas McDonaghof Tummery Road, Irvinestown of fraud by  representation, by telling the injured party pound, already paid out would be edhe in turn paid them pound, and doing so with menaces.The other defendants are Lisnaskea couple Christopher Francis McGovernand Sandra Morrisonfrom of Trasna Way are jointly charged with demanding pound from the injured party with menaces.Overall it is claimed the combined incidents occurred on ious dates between September  and January .While Fermanagh Magistrates Court was previously advised the case would be moving to trial, lawyers for the accused announced their intention to challenge some of the prosecution evidence.The committal hearing took the form of a preliminary investigation in which the injured party and two police officers were cross-exanimated on aspects of their evidence.Due to the nature of these hearings, the content cannot be published at this time.However, after this concluded, barristers for all four defendants contended on the basis of what was disclosed, their respective clients should not be ed for trial.But District Judge Steven Keown rejected their argument and held the prosecution case ldquohad not fallen short. He ruled there is satisfied there is a case to answer against all defendants, and any evidence which was disputed is a matter for the crown court.The committal procedure went ahead during which the defendants chose not to call witnesses or give evidence on their own behalf.Judge Keown remanded them on existing bail to appear before Dungannon Crown Court for formal arraignment next month.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: welsh trekkers raise   marie curie hospice
story: The team included Marie Curie nurses, volunteers, and family members of those cared for by the charity, with the proceeds going to people in need across the country - including Penarthrsquos own Marie Curie hospice.They tackled demanding daily hikes of up to eight hours and took on the valleys and paddy fields of northern Vietnam.Lisa Richards, a Marie Curie nurse from Rhuddlan, was part of the group and has raised more than pound, for the charityrsquos services across Wales.Ms Richards has been working for the charity for almost  years and lost six stone in preparation for the challenge.She said: ldquoI am always amazed by the fantastic fundraisers who work tirelessly giving their time and energy to raise money for the charity, so thatrsquos why this year I wanted to be a part of that process.ldquoI was supported every step of the way on the trek by a fantastic group of people who lted me up when I stumbled and made me feel like Irsquod known them forever and Irsquove really made friends for le.Mariclare Carey-Jones, a BBC journalist and broadcaster and ambassador for the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale hospice, took part in the challenge.ldquoAs an ambassador for the Vale hospice I know how important fundraising is in order to ensure the organisation can continue providing vital care and support for people with terminal illnesses and their families, she said.ldquoKnowing I could give something back to this fantastic charity that has done so much for me and my family was my main motivation for signing up to the Vietnam trek, while the opportunity to experience a new country and undertake an amazing challenge was a real added bonus.Now the charity is calling on people to sign up for its next trek to Patagonia, which will see funds raised for the Marie Curie Nursing Service across Wales - including care in the home and the hospice.Last year, Marie Curie nurses cared for more than , patients and their families across Wales, at a cost of more than poundm a year.Hannah Leckie, community fundraiser for Cardf and the Vale, said: ldquoOur treks are always very popular, whether itrsquos with people looking to take on a new challenge in a beautul country with stunning landscapes, or those whose family has been cared for at the hospice and want to give something back.ldquoWe think Patagonia could be the best adventure yet.ldquoIt will be offering all those taking part the trip of a letime while raising money for such an important local cause.To find out more about the Patagonia trek and to register your place, visit: https:tinyurl qpxnlf article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: gin  celebrate first birthday launch penarth gin
story: Gin , of Victoria Road, plans to celebrate their its birthday with a party on November .Over the course of the year, the enterprising owners ndash Ashley Boucher and Jacques Aviles ndash have seen the bar go from strength to strength, getting involved in the manufacturing process and even being filmed by BBC Wales.Penarth Gin was described by manager Gareth Llywellyn as a premium, triple distilled Welsh dry gin, naturally prominent with notes of juniper, liquorice, cardamom citrus, orris root and paradise.Mr Boucher said: ldquoFrom humble beginnings we have had a successful year and we can only thank our customers and staff for ensuring such a prosperous start, turning our dreams into reality.ldquoAs soon as we opened we knew we would be interested in venturing into the spirit manufacturing market and have since produced our very own Penarth Gin.Mr Aviles said: ldquoWe were selected by the BBC to take part in a new docuseries highlighting successful Welsh businesses run by young entrepreneurs. It looks at the journey each business has been through to get to where they are now and what plans they have for the future.ldquoGin  was chosen for its unique style and that we set it up together, two cousins under the age of .ldquoFilming took place over four sessions in the last six months, with the final planned shoot for the first year anniversary party. Wersquore very excited.Mr Boucher and Mr Aviles, along with new business partner David Cole, now plan to expand across South Wales and the West Country.The programme will be aired sometime before Christmas with the exact date still to be set. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
